column24: UNNATI was formed by Shri. C. Mohammed a retired State Civil Service Officer of A&N Islands in 2000 which is working in the field of Rural Development, Social Welfare and self employment in partnership with Rajiv Gandhi Foundation, New Delhi, UNICEF, Rashtriya Mahila Kosh, New Delhi, NABARD, AWAKE, Care India, Centre for Processed Food, Food and Extension Unit, Ministry of HRD, Agriculture Technical Management Agency (ATMA), Departments of Social Welfare, Rural Development, Industries, Animal Husbandry, Agriculture etc. of A&N Administration and carried out various promotional, awareness programmes. The main achievements of UNNATI are as under:- All round development of children in partnership with UNICEF and Social Welfare Department and reduced the mal-nutrition status from 47% to 27%. which was a record achievement appreciated by UNICEF. The capacity and skill of all anganwadi teachers of Andaman and Nicobar Islands (561) were improved by arranging quality training. Organised 27 motivational programme for self-employment, 261 Self Help Groups were formed and were given training for capacity building in partnership with Rashtriya Mahila Kosh, New Delhi and NABARD. 27 Self Help Groups were arranged loan from different financial institutions. 14 training programme for capacity building and skill-up-gradation in food processing was organised in partnership with Rajiv Gandhi Foundation, New Delhi. 30 Farmers Interest Groups were also formed in partnership with ATMA and they were assisted to undertake income generation activities besides training in food processing. Unemployed youth cooperative societies were also formed by UNNATI in association with A & N State Cooperative Union and they were assisted to get work from Govt. Departments. Working for the welfare of tribal youth in association with Nicobari Youth Tribal Council and organised 5 workshops in Nancowry for implementation of NREGA and advocacy for tobacco control. Organized 30 NREGA workshops in different Panchayats for general awareness of NREGA in association with DRDA and District Administration. 18 training programmes were conducted in Animal Husbandry, Dairy Farming and fisheries related activities in association with A & N Administration. Organized following health related meetings/awareness programmes in association with health department & PRIs: 1. Mothers meeting - 710 2. Awareness meeting for child care and nutrition - 522 3. Sanitation meeting - 399 Working in the field of adolescents and organised 5 workshops. UNNATI has been nominated by Rajiv Gandhi National Institute of Youth Development, Sriperumbudur. 19 widows were assisted to avail widow pension. UNNATI is also taking up various civic issues and welfare issues with the Administration. UNNATI is a member of Confederation of NGOs, AWAKE and Advocacy Forum for Tobacco Control (AFTC). Because of active participation and involvement of UNNATI in Rural Development works, the chief functionary of UNNATI was also nominated as expert Members of U.T Level NREGA committee.

column24: Overview on Aarohan Foundation: Conceptualized and founded by a group of alumni from IITs and IIMs, Aarohan Foundation is a non-profit organisation working in the areas of education and livelihoods for the underserved .It has an advisory council of leading Global executives having work experience in varied areas like project management, IT outsourcing, sales and marketing, finance, human resources, training and development etc. Aarohan provides livelihood solutions for different target groups like women, differently abled, PLHAs, etc. by empowering through skill building and handholding which are crucial for converting micro credit into micro-enterprise. Aarohans focus is on vocational education, and Micro enterprise development at grass root level. It has its presence in Hyderabad, Bhubaneswar, Bihar and Delhi and works in alliance with Government, NGOs and the pool of volunteers and donors. Some of its achievements: 1. Vocational training for the youth â€“ IT School Bhubaneswar The objective is to give vocational training for employment self-employment for unprivileged students. It imparts a combination of computer basics, typing, Spoken English, Personality Development after which students are placed in various sectors (Computer Center, Pharmacy, Retail, Corporate Sector, etc) or opt for higher studies. 2. Micro enterprise creation: Aarohan Foundation held awareness sessions and has conducted a Business Plan Competition at Hyderabad for PWDs (persons with disability) as the part of Abilities Mela 2009 to encourage the spirit of entrepreneurship and channel it through creation of micro enterprise. Some e.g.: â€¢ Aarohan has set up a shoemaking unit for group of differently abled, rehabilitated from the begging profession and has provided machines, and other support. â€¢ A tailoring unit for women â€¢ A coin box and bike repair shop for PWD â€¢ Microfinance: In addition to the skill building and venture management support Aarohan also provides financial and raw material support to micro enterprise in chosen cases. â€¢ Marketing support: Aarohan gives market linkage for products made by various vulnerable groups. It does through periodic exhibitions and corporate orders for their products and an e-mart is to start soon. 3. Women Empowerment: Aarohan works for empowering women by skill building, awareness and market linkage in areas like Jute bag making, tailoring, Zardosi and embroidery work for groups of women from various underserved communities in and around Hyderabad, leading to typical income enhancement from about Rs.1500 to about Rs.3000 per month. 4. Rural development: 1. Vocational training for youth and women. 2. School education at village level, currently in Bihar. 5. Children: Education and livelihood support for children of various categories like Orphans, Street children, Children from juvenile home, etc. Aarohan Foundation is working in juvenile homes of Hyderabad to facilitate skill building programs like art, craft, personality development, computer basics and other relevant skills and also organize trainings for instructors for skill up â€“ gradation.

column24: ABHAYA is striving for the upliftment of Rural poor& concentrate mainly on Health, Education, Environment, Vocational-trainings, Irrigation and Agriculture and conducting surveys & Impact assessments For the past 13 years, ABHAYA achieved the follwing under various activities & projects: (A) HEALTH: 1. Arranging vaccination camps & Health awareness programmes like awareness on seasonal diseases, Nutrition for mother & child 2. AIDS awareness programmes like sending the AIDS suspected persons to nearby ART centres, developing self confidence and optimism in HIV patients, distributing broachers etc 3. Providing free medicines, artificial limbs, wheel chairs, hearing aids to the needy poor 4. Conducting community sensitization programme on Maternal Health And Perinatal Death Inquiry & Response (MAPEDIR) to decrease the Maternal deaths All these activities are done by us wiht the help of DM & HO, and local clubs in Warangal, R.R. & Nalgonda districts (B) EDUCATION: ABHAYA had run Child Labour schools & creches for children with support of Govt. funds in Warangal from 1996 to 2004. (C) Women Empowerment: As a part of thrift programmes, ABHAYA had organized 150 SHGs in Warangal. We provided vocational trainings like tailoring, embroidery, pickle making, papad making etc (D) Environmental awareness: We are participating in National Environmental Awareness Programme (NEAC) every year in rural areas comprising of 2 components: Under Awareness component, we are providing awareness on Organic farming & under Activity component, we are establishing vermi compost units, an eco friendly fertilizer production unit. (E) Legal awareness: We provided free legal guidance to farmers on Right to Information, Human Rights, Women & Child Rights etc. (F) PROJECTS: We are providing Supporting services as a Supporting Organization (SO) under Andhra Pradesh Community Based Tank Management Project (APCBTMP) & Andhra Pradesh State Irrigation Development Corporation (APSIDC) in R.R., Warangal, Nalgonda & Guntur; both of which are on going Govt. projects funded by World Bank and Govt. of India implemented by I & CAD dept. We provided Institutional strengthening and Capacity building Trainings. We have formed Raithu-Mitra groups and CIGs. Also arranged agriculture demonstrations on new technological basis, Exposure visits & promoted Agriculural Livelihood Supporting Services (ALSS) activities. MAJOR ACHIEVEMENTS: In villages where we are organising Health awareness programmes the people are now well aware of vaccinations and the no. of beneficiaries are increasing by 10 to 15 % every year. We feel we had a great achievement by the response of these beneficiaries. It is because of our project MAPEDIR and the benefits provided by the Govt. that allmost all the pregnant women are encouraged Institutional deliveries. We organized 150 SHGs which are now merged into IKP. Among these, about 20 groups had established own tailoring shops & most of these women are earnings their Livelihood on Dairy etc. We are the first to organize Environmental Awareness programmes for Water Users Associations (WUA), Farmers Associations (FA) & farmers. Women were given least priority in all circumstances in Rural areas above cited programmes. But now we made them actively participate equivalent to men in project activities by incorporating them as members in WUA & FA giving gender importance. Though WUAs were established in most of the villages, the members were not aware of their Roles & Reponsibilities. We provided the necesary trainings and orientations on Societies functioning and awared them on their Roles & Responsibilities. We also facilitated them in arranging WUA/ FA offices in their respective villages and collection of corpus fund. This corpus fund helps them to face or overcome minor problems in future without seeking for Govt. help. We also trained them in Book keeping. Now for every WUA/FA, Corpus fund exists in Banks of not less than Rs. 40,000 /-. We facilitated them in identifying & appointing para workers & Crew members provided with the necessary trainings which further resulted in the promotion of their Livelihood. Also we facilitated the Crew members in taking Insurance policies. In the Project APCBTMP, we made the Ayacutdars donate their land worth of 1.2 to 1.5 lakhs for the construction of path towards their Tanks. The tank by name "Pedda cheruvu" of Uddamarri village in which we re working as an S.O. under APCBTMP was published as a successful story in a website.

column24: I am very happy to inform you about the below mentioned Seva programmes are takenup sofar. 1. Mentally challenged persons : We are conducted Medical camp especially Mentally challenged persons for treatment with free of services through Dr. K. Ramakrishna Anand, as the mentally challenged persons are suffering ill health dueto non availability of Doctors in Government Hospitals. 2. Providing of Oxygen facility :in view of the suffering of the people due to non availability of Oxygen, Abhimani Foundation is providing free Oxygen supply for the needful persons. 3. Conducting of Eye camps : In our rural area most of the people suffering with Eye defects. In view of that our trust conducted Eye camps regularly and examined 724 patients and also operated 164 persons through NRI Hospital , Visakhapatnam. 4. Awareness Camps : 1) People located in rural area and tribal areas are suffering from Nutrition deficiency. Inview of that we conducted awareness campaign on Food and Nutrition in Tribal areas and educated them. 2) In these days every day we are facing so many Road accidents. Inview of that we conducted awareness campaigns so as to Motor workers to avoid road accidents. 3) Every two month being is using Polythene eventhough it is having pollution so a special awareness programme is under took by the trust and we are conducting special pogrammes to the people and making them to avoid using of Polythene as a Special work shop. 4)To educate the people and students on eradication the HIV/AIDS in our society, seminars are being conducted 5. Spoken English : To increase the competitive skills among the student especially in English. Our trust conducting Spoken English and personality development programme since Aprilâ€™2009 to till to date and sofar covered 174 students sofar inthis programme 6. Sports & Games :To improve physical fitness to youth. Our trust conducted shuttle badmaintain, Cricket, Chess district level tournament 7. National Integration : In order to bring motivation among the general public, we conducted 5K RUN Programme to promote National Integrity which was been got attention of not only Bobbili but also the entire district and large number of people participated. 8. Blood donation : To serve the people in emergency cases. Our trust conducted 4 blood camps and provided the same to the people who are required blood in emergency cases. 9. Financial Assistances : In the inauguration function of ABHIMANI FOUNDATION promise to provide Two Sewing machines to Widow womens and also to provide financial assistance to the students who are in need to pay the examination fee. 10. Health Cards : In consultation of repeated 6 Doctors and their help the trust is able to issue health cards to put people who are now gating free consultation charges and 10% discount on their purchase of medicines form some medical shops. The further charity programmes under took by us are 1. Rehabilitation center at Bobbili Mandal will be started shortly in view of to serve Psychiatric patients, Physically challenged persons. 2. To organize Old age Home 3. Conduct awareness camps on HIV/AIDS, Blood donation, Environmental, Road safety, Food and nutrition etc., 4. To provides services to farmers on agriculture programmes. 5. Take up Plantation inview of to protect Environmental. 6. Other service programmes

column24: The Abid Ali Khan Educational Trust was constituted in the year 1993, since then it has played very important role in promoting education across all the section of society. The trust has played a major role in safe guarding Urdu language and off course its promotion.The trust has taught Urdu to nearly 15 lakh plus students irrespective of religion, caste, creed and culture. The Trust conducts Urdu Dani,Urdu Zabani Dani and Urdu Insha exams twice annually and successful students are awarded with certificates. Trust distributes education material free of cost. column24: Academicians Association for Liberation, Peace and Education (AALPE) is secular voluntary organization registered under societies registration Act XXI of 1860 with registration no. 993 /1992 started in the year 1992 with a high level of commitment and experience by young professional in health and social development sectors. The founder of the organization has 15 years of experience in ground level implementation in community based projects. APPLEâ€™ is also registered under FCRA Act with Registration No. 010170157 and also under Section 80G & 12A of the Income Tax Act 1961. The organization has started its activities rural villages of East Godavari District of Andhra Pradesh. The major activivties include Andhra pradesh community based Tank management, water and sanitation, HIV&AIDS, Vocational trainings for women and girls and Reproductive child health projects. Vision: To strive for comprehensive rural development through the welfare of weaker section of the society Mission : To relieve the population particularly from their existing poverty, economic depression and to help them for the progress of educational, cultural, moral social, health, and economic standards of living by undertaking various constructive activities.

column24: The Academy of Grassroots Studies and Research of India has successfully organised 8 Bharat Ratna Rajiv Gandhi Memorial Lectures and presented the Bharat Ratna Rajiv Gandhi Outstanding Leadership, Mahila Shakti, Yuva Shakti,Best District, Best Taluk and Best Gram Panchayat Awards since 2005 onwards, besides regular National Conferences/Seminars/Workshops/Round Tables and research publications of The Grassroots Governance Journal (Bi-annual in English) and Gram Sabha (Telugu Magazine). The Academy has published a large number of occasional papers, working papers and research books on panchayti raj, rural development, women empowerment, good governance and related subjects. The Academy Director has visited Pakistan and Norway, as one of the Members of Indo-Pak Delegation and Indo-Norway Delegation, led by Shri Mani Shankar Aiyar, the then Union Minister for Panchayati Raj, Govt. of India, in the year 2007.

column24: A R C H I E S ACADEMY OF RURAL CHILDRENâ€™S HEALTH AND INTEGRATED EDUCATIONAL SOCIETY Administrative Office : Balajirao Pet, TENALI â€“ 522 201, Guntur District, (A.P.) GENESIS : ARCHIES was established by a group of committed social workers with the aim of bringing development into the lives of rural, urban communities with access to credit, and income generation programme for self reliance. The Organisation was registered under Societies Registration Act XXI of 1860 vide Regd.No.478/1995. The organization was also registered under F.C.R.A. with the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi. The organisation was also registered under Section 12 A A of Income Tax Act. Location of the Administrative Office : The Administrative Office of the organisation is located in Tenali on Chennai to Vijayawada Trunk Line. Objectives of the Organisation : The Objectives of the Organisation are as follows : 1. To provide qualitative Educational opportunities to the rural poor girls and women. 2. To promote health and sanitation programmes for prevention from infections disease and water born diseases. 3. To preserve the rural environment and ecology. 4. To promote access of Micro Credit for income generation programmes. 5. To provide qualitative training to the target groups in the fields of Education, Health, Environment, Thrift and Savings. 6. To Organise Health Camps in the villages.

column24: Accelerated Common Communities Empowerment Service Society short name as ACCESS, a not-for-profit Non Governmental Organisation, is promoted by a group committed Professionals to address the issues around the poverty in rural and urban areas in Adilabad, Hyderabad, Khammam, Karimnagar, Nalgonda, Rangareddy and Warangal Districts in Andhra Pradesh, registered under the Andhra Pradesh (Telangana Area) Public Societies Registration Act,1350 Falsi (ActIof1350F) Registered in April 1994 with Registration No.2001. The organization is previously known as Suma Educational Society (SES) and in November 2006 it has been changed its name as Accelerated Common Communities Empowerment Service Society (ACCESS). ACCESS is implementing various welfare and development programmes for Women and Deserved since 1994, the major programmes dealing with Education, Health includes Consultancy Services for Facilitating Implementation of Social Management Plan including Resettlement Action Plan as Package NGO in Jagithyal-Peddapalli Road from Km 0.000 to 58.750, Child Labour eradication programme, Waste Land Development programmes, Women and Child welfare programmes and Non Pesticides Management. It is having around 76 regular and volunteerâ€™s staff for various projects and programmes. These include 24 technical and managerial staff. The human resources available with ACCESS are having wider experiences with research, data collection, analysis and report writing, Groundwater Management Action Plans (GWMAP) & Social and Environmental Management Plans (SEMP), as it is working across 7 Districts in the state of Andhra Pradesh, the sectoral implications across the districts are well tailored into the capacities of human resource of ACCESS. Besides, it is having very good network and database of resource persons, researchers, technicians and documenters. With the technical institution collaborations, ACCESS is actively engaging in data collection, setting of indicators, impact measuring with control groups, monitoring mechanisms, besides project formulations and establishing various systems for data updating and validity checking.

column24: ALS aim to initiate/ implement development programs/ projects, in community development field any where in India particularly in Andhra Pradesh. ALS also aims to promote, support, sustain and offer appropriate support to developmental initiatives/ projects/ activities for integrated human development. (a)Plan and formulate development projects independently or in association with other rganisations /groups/individuals, for implementation by itself or through other organisations/groups/ individuals engaged in development programs. (b) Evolve and implement programs and schemes to support rural development work to enhance the quality of life of the poor in rural/ urban and tribal areas c). Evolve and implement programs and schemes to support/ sustain the existing institutions or the institutions likely to come up. (d) Provide professional, technical, and management assistance towards rural/ tribal/ urban development and related programs; (e) Serve as a development resource centre to organisations/ groups/ individuals, involved/ interested in rural/ urban/ tribal development field. (f) Help organisations/ groups/ individuals, involved in development field, wherever possible and/or necessary, directly or through others in mobilising institutional, financial, technical and professional support; (g) Conduct/ coordinate/ facilitate social, economic, ecological, livelihoods and development research studies; and (h) Take up such other activities as may be necessary from time to time for furthering and promoting the objectives of ALS. ALS is an young organisation with young professionals who have potential experience and expertise in sustainable livelihoods. The organisation is approaching many institutions to get support to develop sustainable business models for rural economy. The Institution is yet get postive response and support to kick start its journey to see a great India. Yet this moment we can promise any institution that we surely get feed back from the support institution that we have shown an example of morethan the committed to them.

column24: We have made a substantial contribution since 1986 in Anantapur district with our Participatory Watershed Development Programme. It was perhaps the largest participatory watershed programme by an NGO in India spread over about 300 villages, covering about 1.35 lakh ha of farm land and 60,000 farmers. We are known for our participatory approach and very high quality in watershed development on a sizable scale. The major interventions under the watershed programme included Soil and Moisture Conservation, Rain Water Harvesting, Horticulture, Rainfed Agronomical Practices, Bio-gas and peoples Institutional Development.

column24: Worked in 12 villages of Bantwaram Mandal in Ranga Reddy District of Andhra Pradesh. Under the sponsorship program of ActionAid, the project adopted village development area approach at micro level, thus including all the families of the target area as eligible members of the programs. It was an integrated approach involving the health, education, agriculture, livelihoods and microfinance areas to alleviate poverty though empowering the community. AID worked with funding from AP SACS in the school l& workplace interventions in slums of Hyderabad during 2003, and 2004. During the period of work we conducted mega camps on HIV / AIDs awareness programs As per the agreement ActionAid funding discontinued from March 2003. However we are continuing our work in the DA in the advisory capacity with MACS, supporting their systems.

column24: ALL HEALTH-EDUCATIONAL RURAL DEVEMOPMENT SOCIETY ( AHERDS ), PENUKONDA, A.P is a non-Governmental voluntary organization as it was started by a few committed members who has desire and experience in the field of rural development. It has resource managerial straits and experienced personal drawn from several sectors for caring our activities of the organization. It does not determine any on the ground of sex, religion, region, language, caste of creed etc.,. It has evolved various innovative approaches for integrated development among it target groups like Minority Muslims, women, children, SC, ST, BC aged and resembled the intervention of the Organisation include socio, cultural, health, community organization, thrift and credit through SHGs and other rural development programmes. A view to cover the uncovered villages by NGOs to make the rural poor the parents in rural development with the previous experience in the field of rural development and as well as with the interaction and living experience with the rural poor and its learnt that unless. The part of the development process in AHERDS endeavor towards the development of the poor i.e., S.C, ST, BC, Minority Muslims AHERDS will also not become a in social change hence AHERDS it is organization determines the self respect movement and development activities should go together. For the 11 years so much time has spent by AHERDS team in educating the poor and marginalized i.e., rural poor and Minorities about human rights alternative in development and last succeed to generate a kind of environment conductive for development. We are of the view that development is a process which makes the people feel that something is being done for relieving their agony. AHERDS believes that the process that should accelerate the piece of social charge put a brake and tendencies leading to social distortion and decadance. A large suffering from the deprevention and permitted for a and direct development that station become transparency on their faces. Thus our strategy for development is one of bringing about a social change a strategy to provide opportunities to the people who are trapped in vicious circle of poverty and backwardness to emerge and make them participants in all fields of human activity.

column24: Awareness programs: ARDSI Hyderabad Deccan conducts lectures and seminars to raise the awareness of dementia at public forums such as senior citizens organziations, social clubs, corporates, colleges and schools. ARDSI Hyderabad Deccan partners with AASARA-GHMC for bi-monthly awareness sessions at Senior Citizens forums in Hyderabad. Memory Clinic: The Memory Clinic at the Nizamâ€™s Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS) provides multidisciplinary care and expertise in assessment, diagnosis and management of persons with dementia. Services offered include medical support, diagnosis, treatment, counselling and speech therapy. Caregivers Meetings A "Theme based" meeting for family caregivers, volunteers and healthcare professionals is conducted on the second Saturday of every month at the Memory Clinic, NIMS. Covering various aspects of dementia care, these support group meetings are both informative and therapeutic, effectively extending the support network to family caregivers. Helpline A 24 hr helpline for effective community outreach is provided Research ARDSI Hyderabad Deccan, in collaboration with the memory clinic at NIMS, is conducting: An epidemiological survey to study prevalence and incidence of dementia in urban and rural centers Research in communication interventions for a bi-lingual population Literature ARDSI Hyderabad Deccan has published caregivers manual, What is Dementia brochures and various other materials in English and local languages. Training Programs ARDSI Hyderabad Deccan conducts training programs for caregivers and healthcare professionals including induction training in dementia care and functional rehabilitation of persons with dementia. A Short-term training course is conducted for home attendants in practical aspects of dementia care, in collaboration with AASARA(GHMC), and the Pain Relief and Palliative Care Society, Hyderabad. Home Visits As part of the person-centered care approach, trained volunteers conduct home-visits, which include patient and caregiver interviews, education of family members to the nature and progression of disease, suggestions of environmental modifications and functional interventions to improve the quality of life of the patient and family. Guidance and Counselling Counseling is provided to care givers on regular basis. Caregivers are encouraged to discuss their experiences with staff and constructive advice is shared. Caregivers manuals and helpsheets on several practical aspects of dementia care such hygiene, feeding, mobility, communication, activities are also provided. Other Activities: Memory Screening Camps, Observation of World Alzheimers Day - September 21, National Consultative Meeting of Experts on the National Dementia Strategy

column24: Details of Achievements of â€œ AMMAVODIâ€ ( Accurate Mothers Movement Association of Voluntary Organizing Development Integration ) requested under society Registration Act. AMMAVODI Voluntary Organization â€“ Venkampeta Village â€“ Parvatipuram mandal â€“ V izianagaram district â€“ Andhra Pradesh state . This organization is specially conducted welfare programs in rural areas for the development of women. Our society target area population mostly, ST, SC and BC community as per Aims and objects. Priority have been given to the traibal, dalith women and oldaged development activities. WOMEN AWARENESS : We formed 8 Self Help Groups ( SHG) . Each group consisits of 10 t o 13 members. Through our NGO, we helped the groups for various purposes like Bank Loan facilities participation in Abhayastam Government Scheme . Schemes for development of women like Am Admee Insurance Scheme. CHILD LABOUR AWARENESS : Ammavodi have been providing toys, paly board, nutrition food, Slates, Cloths, etc., to the below 0-4 years children some child awarenss and Child Labour Awareness programmes have also conducted in various villages in this financial year with concerned expert resource person. HEALTH AWARENESS : Now a days the burning problem is spreading of HIV/AIDS. We, the team of Ammavodi organized street plays and Rallies on HIV/ AIDS and how to help the positive people these rallies and street plays given much impact. Youth, both male and female impressed very much. And we organized a camp for Swineflew Awareness. AGRICULTURAL AWARENESS : We conducted the Rythu Chaitanya Sadssulu in various villages in agricultural sector in Parvatipuram mandal. EDUCATIONAL AWARENESS : We organized literacy groups in different villages in the illiterate people of Self Help Groups ( SHG) women. ENVIRONMENTAL AWARENESS : We have conducted 6 environment awareness programmes in different villages with different experts â€“ Air pollution, Traffic and accidents awareness, Clean and Green, Drinking Water, Underground water awareness programmes have conducted in Parvatipuram mandal more than 1500 participants attended to above these awareness programmes around the society, for this programme. HUMAN RESOURCE AWARENESS : To impact training for Skill Development programmes ( Tailoring, Embroidery, Arya works and Computer training, Self Employment income generation mainly to youth and women.

column24: Andhra Pradesh Productivity Council (APPC), Hyderabad is an Autonomous Non-Profit making body established in the year 1958, by the Government of Andhra Pradesh. The Council has been promoting Productivity Awareness in Industrial and Business Houses, Service Sectors, Government and Rural sectors through its multifarious activities like Techno-Management Consultancy, HRD & Energy, Computers, Education and Rural Development for more than four decades. Based on its performance both in terms of the consistent turnover achieved and the spread of its activities, the Council was adjudged as the â€œBest Productivity Councilâ€ in the Country. The Council has been in the field of Urban / Rural Development Programmes, promoting a variety of self-employment schemes and poverty alleviation programmes for nearly two decades. Salient features of major assignments carried out and end results are as follows: EDP To SETWIN Beneficiaries. Eradication of Manual Scavenging Programme. Rural Marketing Service Centre. EDP to PMRY Beneficiaries. EOP to CMEY Groups â€“ Old Groups. EDP to CMEY Groups â€“ New Groups. Skill Development Programme to SHGâ€™s â€“ DRDA. Basic Orientation Programme to SHGâ€™s â€“ DRDA. Entrepreneurship Orientation Programmes â€“ SC Beneficiaries. Rural Industries Programme. Rural Employment Generation Programme â€“ KVIC. Rural Entrepreneurship Development Programme â€“ NABARD. Rural Entrepreneurship Development Programme â€“ SIDBI EDP to Women (APWCF) Census and assessment of distribution and commercial losses of Agricultural Pump sets Diagnostic survey of incipient and sick units Survey and Evaluation of Deepam Scheme Survey and Evaluation of SGSY Scheme Survey and Evaluation of National Old Age Pension Scheme in Five Districts Potential opportunities Assessment survey Detailed Survey and Evaluation of Bio â€“diesel Plantations Impact assessment survey of Horticulture Schemes under SHM Status Survey and evaluation of Micro Irrigation systems in all Districts Impact Assessment survey of Horticulture Plantations under National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme

column24: Education contributes largely to development of a personality and society. The Society was started in the year 1935 . A strong conviction of the society at that time, and to this day, is emancipation of women socially and economically through education. Towardsthis objective the Society diversified its activities. A Sisu Vihar was started in the year 1955, a full fledged high school in the year 1968-69, a junior College in the year 1995, and a Degree College in the year 1998. Encouraged y the performance of these institutuins, the Society has started PG course of MBA and a proffessional course B-Pharmac with a permitted strength of 60 in each , from the academic year 2009-10. The Andhra Yuvathi Mandali has years of long life committed to the services of women and children in the society deprived of the opportunities for education, health and development. The Society ,as a policy, keeps the fee structure of all its Institutions at a lower level than others in the area in order to cater to the economically weaker sections of the society .

column24: APMAS is a national-level technical and managerial support institution with a vision, â€œSustainable self-help movement in Indiaâ€. It works for womenâ€™s empowerment and poverty alleviation through capacity building, quality assessment, livelihood promotion, communication and research & advocacy on a fee-for-service basis. APMAS is funded by DFID through CARE India, Ford Foundation, Aga Khan Foundation, and InWEnt. APMAS became fully operational in July 2001 and today it has a functional team of 40 professionals providing services to diverse stakeholders across the state and in a limited way to other states. A variety of tools and content have been developed to take up Quality Assessment (rating) and capacity building services. Towards wider dissemination of best practices and for impacting the quality of community based institutions, APMAS publishes a monthly magazine called Mahila Sadhikaratha (Women Empowerment), conducts National Immersion Programmes for all stakeholders, and is establishing a national virtual resource centre for SHG stakeholders (www.shggateway.in). APMAS has developed strong networks with the Department of Women Empowerment & Self Employment, SERP, APRLP, PRIA, NABARD, Andhra Bank and other state level institutions. APMAS has responded to requests for capacity building support from training institutions located in Hyderabad like NIRD, MANAGE, APARD, ICM and other.

column22: Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Gujarat, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Orissa, Uttar Pradesh
column24: APMAS originated in 2001 out of a need for an institution which provides capacity building for both primary and secondary stakeholders and which ensures quality promotion and management in SHG institutions. Since inception, APMAS has been actively supported by the Government, Banks, NGOs and Community Based Organizations. APMAS is registered as a Non-Governmental public society and stands under the Foreign Contribution Regulation Act, 1976. APMAS quickly established itself as a unique, credible, and pioneering support organization in the field of SHG promotion. APMAS is a professionally managed organization with a devoted governing board and dedicated staff. The Board of APMAS consists of 21 representatives from the government, NGOs, financial institutions and banks, academic institutions, SHG federations, and eminent individuals. APMAS has adopted, and is adhering to, international standards for internal systems. These internal systems include a comprehensive Human Resource policy, Financial System, proactive Staff Training and Development, and involvement programmes. APMAS strongly believes in partnerships and collaborations for achieving its vision and mission. By generating internal funds through a â€œfee for servicesâ€ strategy, APMAS has emerged as a new generation NGO and aims to be self-reliant. APMAS is a National Level Organization. It provides field support to the staff of SERP on institutional building, covering their work in 11 districts, 90 mandals, and working with MEPMA piloting in 3 towns of Andhra Pradesh. APMAS extended its support activities to 5 states of India: Bihar, Gujarat, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh. APMAS is providing Capacity Building support to 13 districts of Bihar, one district of Orissa, one district of Gujarat and two districts of Madhya Pradesh, one district in Uttar Pradesh. Apart from direct Capacity Building, APMAS has strong collaboration with ENABLE members in Policy Advocacy and Capacity Building in the states of Karnataka, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Rajasthan, West Bengal and other states in Northeast, East and Central India. Unique services by APMAS for strengthening the SHG Movement APMAS core business is building capacities of the Self Help Promoting Agencies (SHPAs) through Quality Assessment (rating), Quality Enhancement, Research & Advocacy and Livelihoods Promotion Services to SHGs and SHG Federations through their promoters. Quality Enhancement Capacity Building (CB) to the primary, secondary, and tertiary stakeholders in the SHG movement holds the key for long-term sustainability of both SHGs and their federations. Various capacity-building initiatives taken up by APMAS in Andhra Pradesh and the other states have brought greater recognition to APMAS in the country. CB focuses on training of trainers based on needs assessment, hand-holding support, follow-up of training conducted, facilitating exposure visits, material development and enabling the process of problem solving at the field level. Field visits are undertaken to provide on-the-job support and to demonstrate good practices in the filed. The key initiatives under this unit are expansion of the SHG support services to the other states and promotion of the urban SHG movement. Over the past 8 years, APMAS has trained more than 80,000 professionals and SHG federation representatives. Quality Assessment (Ratings) Rating of SHG federations contributes to their sustainability. Through six rating tools that have been designed by APMAS over the last 8 years, it has assessed 434 SHG federations of various promoting Organizations. The findings of the assessments have been disseminated widely to gather consensus on the need of building necessary systems and processes in order to make the SHG federations institutionally and financially sustainable. APMAS ratings have been extensively used by SHPIs to improve the quality of their functioning, and assisting their efforts to acquire â€œseed capitalâ€ from externally funded projects. APMAS is recognized as a specialized agency for SHG federation rating in India. Livelihood promotion APMAS strategically chooses to support different livelihood interventions by strengthening the role of community based organisations (CBOs) in leading their livelihoods sustainably. Thus, APMAS created its niche role in supporting different livelihood activities across different sectors, with an approach denoted through a connotation Sustainable institutions for sustainable livelihoods. APMAS initiated its interventions in supporting Livelihood Promotional activities as an integrated unit established within the organisation in 2004. This was done with the financial support from the Aga Khan Foundation (AKF), under its Sustainable Community-based Approaches for Livelihood Enhancement (SCALE) project funded by the European Union (EU). Through this unit, APMAS plays a catalytic role in promoting rural livelihoods in collaboration with Government of Andhra Pradesh and other livelihood promotion supporting organizations. The key objectives of this unit is to integrate livelihood promotion initiatives by synergizing with the Institution Building, Capacity building processes among CBOs and thus develop these institutions to lead their livelihood activities in farm, off-farm, non-farm and service sectors with which they get associated, in rural India. APMAS provides professional support services to District/ Cluster Livelihood Resource Centers (D/CLRCs) in Adilabad and Kadapa districts to nurture and made them model institutions by creating institutional linkages for livelihood enhancement. It also provides support services in terms of IB, CB and Livelihood Promotional activities for SHGs and their federations under Indira Kranthi Patham (IKP). As part of its initiatives, it conducts few action research studies, develops few demonstrations, provides handholding support and develop case studies out of the best practices. It also organizes events like workshops, immersion programs, flagship programs etc., in facilitating the cross learning process across different stakeholders. Research and Advocacy As a resource organization, APMAS keeps track of the ground realities to provide a wealth of resources to other stakeholders in the development sector. The Research and Advocacy unit is divided into three components: Research, advocacy and communications. Action and applied research is being conducted by the unit on various issues as they emerge and findings from the studies are then used to design capacity building strategies for SHGs, promoting institutions, dissemination of findings through various workshops (advocacy), and made available to the public, through APMAS websites, and publications. Enable To build the profile of SHG movement, to bring issues of SHG movement to the notice of the government and other key stakeholders and to obtain a favorable environment for the healthy growth and sustainability of SHG movement, a National Network Enabling Self Help Movement (Enable) has emerged in 2007 with a vision â€œVibrant Women SHG Movement in Indiaâ€. Currently the network has seven member organizations, viz., APMAS, Hyderabad/Andhra Pradesh; Cmf, Jaipur/Rajasthan; Chaitanya, Rajgurunagar/Maharashtra; GMO, Kolar/Karnataka; ISMW, Ahemadabad; Reach India, Kolkatta; and SHGPF, Kolkatta. Enable is to contribute to a conducive-policy environment through research based advocacy for SHGs and federations, to facilitate the flow of funds for SHG & Federation promotion and on lending, to increase cadre of human resources using standardized training and resource materials for improving quality, to build the profile of the community cased microfinance model, and to promote innovative models for up-scaling and replication. Expansion Programme APMAS is working in 8 states Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, and began to extend its operations in states like Assam, Rajasthan, Gujarat and Orissa, in a phased manner. The states were decided upon with three considerations: firstly, the state would have shown considerable improvement in the quality of the SHG movement. Secondly, the state where institution like APMAS already exists and would show willingness to partner with APMAS; and thirdly, the state where APMAS has already done some work and has some understanding with the local organizations. APMAS explored the possibilities of receiving support from different agencies and succeeded in getting initial support from Sir Dorabji Tata Trust (SDTT) for the states of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh, from Mission Shakti for the state of Orissa, and from AKF (for AKRSP) for the states of Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat. It was decided to explore other collaborators as well within the states. Swayam Niyantrana Udhyamam (SNU) / Self Regulation of SHGs and SHG Federations APMAS is currently engaged in piloting a Swayam Niyantrana Udyamam (SNU) project, with the funding support of DGRV, Germany. The pilot project is being implemented in the Kamareddy Cluster of Nizamabad district of Andhra Pradesh. The overall objective of SNU is to ensure that SHG members set their agenda and manage and control the process, so that the SHG system successfully and sustainably works for the benefit of SHG members. The focus of SNU is to build the capacities of leaders and members in Standardized bookkeeping in use; Standardized reporting in use, Agreed best practices, performance standards and organized monitoring; Framing of policies on accounting, active implementation of policies, business and management; Systematic audit and monitoring of fund security; Systematic election; Capable and own staff; Continuous education/awareness and training; Clarity on General Body (GB), Representative General Body (RBG) Roles of Village Organizations (Primary level SHG Federations) and Mandal Samakya (Secondary level Federations); and Legal Compliances. Urban Interventions APMAS has been collaborating with MEPMA to continue support in strengthening of SHGs and SHG federations to achieve sustainability. Under the programme APMAS has been developing 3 Town-Level-Federations (TLFs) in LB Nagar, Gudivada, and Guntakal urban areas. The total number of SHGs in three towns are 6029 and Slum Level Federations has reached 155 in 2008-09. In all, 17,265 SHG members were trained on SHG Concepts, Federation Concepts and Best Practices. SLFs are undertaking several activities like food security and health in addition to the strengthening of the SHGs in their operational area. APMAS is considering the possibility of providing mentoring support to urban SHG federations to take up activities in the area of water & sanitation as those are considered as very important in urban areas. through their promoters

column24: This Arsha Bharathi Social Welfare Society was established as a voluntary organization during 1999. Our main aim is to serve the poorest human beings and children by promoting social awareness and removing stigma of poverty. Besides taking up several family welfare activities, conducting medical and health camps in rural areas since past Ten years, the society is striving its best to educate women and small farmers on income generation programmes. We are making efforts to establish residential instructions with vocational courses, adult education centers, libraries for girls of rural and slum areas to sensitize the downtrodden sections of society. This could be possible due to having good rapport with government departments and local community. This organization is planning to foster secularism and harmony among people through development programmes. Our endeavour is to ensure sustainable development, harmony, peace, and make the people self-reliant. We mainly focused on awareness programme on different local issues, few are illustrated here under â€¢ Consumer awareness camp â€¢ HIV/AIDS awareness camp â€¢ Income generation training â€¢ Special camp for adolescent girls of tribal areas. â€¢ Free tailoring training â€¢ Organic farming to small farmers â€¢ Adult education programme â€¢ Literacy awareness programme â€¢ Anti Arrack campaign â€¢ Pulse Polio camp â€¢ Health and Blood camp â€¢ Nutrition food to child labour â€¢ General awareness camp â€¢ Seminar against dowry, child and widow marriages â€¢ Shields to merit students â€¢ Clean and green programme at Medaram â€¢ Free eye and medical Camp â€¢ Chickengunya prevention programme â€¢ Cultural programmes for rural youth â€¢ Note books to poor students of SC & BC hostels. This society consists of mainly social workers, small land owners and philanthropists engaged in upliftment of rural weaker sections of this mandal. The objective of protecting the just born kids thrown in dustbins, railways and bus stations etc., Freed those neglected kids by curbing education will be fulfilled if the proposed institutions are built, for which land is being procured from government. Already necessary help is extending to physically handicapped, widows, orphans and senior citizens. As a part of our aims, we are celebrating national festivals like Independence day, Republic day, Birthday celebrations of great leaders who sacrificed their lives to nation like Rajiv Gandhi and celebrated Hindidiwas fortnight pakwara on 25.09.06 and distributed prizes to the winners in examination conducted in Hindi to students of local high school. This Society has organized 150 years First War of Indian Independence celebration. The beneficiaries of our training programmes are encouraging this society to conduct such income generation courses for some other rural youth. In our training programmes, local officials and resourceful persons were assisting and delivering their valuable suggestions to participants. In a year, the society is making efforts to construct own educational institutions at Abdullapue village, R.R dist to commence full-fledged orphan center, old aged home, vocational training institute and research institute to serve more voluntarily.

column24: Counselling and Legal Services: Offering legal support and counseling to survivors of violence has been a major focus of Asmita since its inception. We believe this plays a vital role in empowering individual women who get educated of their human and legal rights with practical guidance on how to obtain justice. A range of women have sought support over the years. Our counseling and legal services are not advertised; yet each year at least 50 women take advantage of these services, learning about them by word-of-mouth. Gender and Development for NGO Women Leaders: Notwithstanding the output of work that women NGO leaders do at the local level and the understanding they have of local issues, an analysis of the deeper connections between the various changes going on in their environment is a welcome addition to their skills. Since the capacity building workshops that we conduct regularly were always full and there was always a rush to attend them, Asmita offers a year long distance cum contact programme, attended every month by representatives from different organisations across the state. Now Gender, Development and Human Rights Course - Year 3 is on. The range of the course is vast and comprehensive - all human rights, linkages to issues such as development, health, globalization, discrimination and violence against women. Women and Disability Rights: To strengthen the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, we in collaboration with Chaitanya Vikalanguala Hakkula Vedika, Mahbubnagar, Andhra Pradesh initiated the workshops and campaigns on Disability Rights. Women and girls with disabilities face all types of discrimination. These workshops will help to support the growth and empowerment of women. Thematic Areas of the project is initiating discussion on disability - its causes, consequences and way forward; introducing the Persons with Disabilities Act, 1995; Gender Equality - - Patriarchy, Sexuality, Reproduction, Violence; Division of labour - gender, disability, age; Child Rights â€“ Violence against girl child with disability at home and outside, child health, child marriage; Poverty and Disability; The feedback of the workshops is positive, the participants expressed that they got awareness on social context of disability and enhance respect and concern for persons with disabilities. Arts and Culture: Using arts and culture as a method of outreach and awareness has proven to be a great way of disseminating our messages to a wide audience. Through Telugu and English films, publications and Indian classical dance performances we have managed to further strengthen our conversations around equality.

column24: ASSIST is non-profit organization supporting disadvantaged communities through different programs in rural Andhra Pradesh. Through twenty four years of experience ASSIST has reached the ability to understand the priorities in the needs of the population and to successfully implement programs to satisfy such needs. ASSIST has phased out from 130 in Andhra Pradesh and is currently working in 347 villages on the following issues: â€¢ Strengthening of community based organisations; 532 Village Development Societies formed of which 456 were registered as societies under Indian Societies Registration Act XXI; â€¢ Child labour â€“ Identifying working children, rehabilitating and mainstreaming them to regular education institutes; 20,230 children enrolled in Government schools from Balwadis, TEC and Residential centres; â€¢ Vocational training and education â€“ Providing training in employability skills to adolescents; 4,305 adolescents trained in vocational skills; â€¢ Women Empowerment - Empowering women through training and financial aid for the creation of small business; 2,301 SHGs formed; 4,671 women trained on Entrepreneurship Development Programme and supported; 34,426 illiterate women educated; 1,136 women trained in vocational skills; â€¢ Livelihood promotion â€“ Helping deprived communities providing business loans for women and men through micro-finance activities, creating micro entrepreneurships; 13,650 families established their own work units and have sustainable income;15 family based Mutually Aided Cooperative Thrift and Credit Societies formed; â€¢ Water and sanitation â€“ Providing drinking water through bore wells and water treatment plants, helping with water harvesting and irrigation bores for agriculture and providing latrines; 1,098 new drinking bore wells provided; 32 protected safe drinking water schemes implemented covering 56,000 people; 19 community-owned and managed Reverse Osmosis Plants established; 125 check dams constructed; 13,569 individual sanitary latrines constructed; 58 sanitary latrines constructed in Government schools; 4 community sanitary latrines constructed; â€¢ Social Housing â€“ Providing secured shelters to poor and helping coastal communities to rebuild homes after disasters; 18,026 families provided with secure shelter; â€¢ Health â€“ Organising health check camps and educating on health and hygiene issues, including HIV/AIDS prevention; 3,297 people covered in dental camps; 115,150 children immunized; 17,184 families mobilised for family planning operations; 3 health centres constructed; â€¢ Sustainable Farming and land development â€“ Training marginal farmers in sustainable agriculture and supporting reforestation; 739 Vermi-compost units created; 3,210 acres of aqua land converted into agricultural land; 19,828 hectares of dry land brought under irrigation; â€¢ Disaster relief â€“ Providing immediate attention and help to areas affected by natural and other disasters.

column24: ARCC is concentizing Chenchu Communities about Conservation of Biodiversity and Enrichment of the Ecosystems of the Nallamala Forests of the Krishna River Valley and educating the Chenchus about extending their support to the officers concerned. It is interacting with Chenchus especially with the women about the ways to increase their productivity through promoting Health, Economic, Education, and restoring their rich Community-Bonds relating to promote Millennium Development Goals for enabling environment for the Holistic Development of the Chenchu Communities in the region. It is endeavoring to establish a Minor Forest Produce collection store a branch of Girijan Co-operative Corporation Ltd.; at Erragondapalem for Chenchusâ€™ produce they collected in the forest, to sell, in their vicinity, instead of going to Dornala, which reduces travel cost and a day of their productive work. It is contacting local contributors and donors for partner with ARCC for Charity and Development Partnerships. ARCC is endeavoring to make partnerships with renowned Scientific Research and Educational Institutions in Andhra Pradesh and across the world. It acquired membership of International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development, and was invited to ARCC to contribute to the July 2009 special edition of the Mountain Forum Bulletin focusing on â€œmountain biodiversityâ€™â€™. It is a unique co- production of the Mountain Forum (MF), Global Mountain Biodiversity Assessment (GMBA) of DIVERSITAS, and the Mountain Research Initiative (MRI). Please refer: http://www.cbd.int/mountain/, also refer: www.mtnforum.org and http://www.icimod.org ARCC was advised by International Union of Forests Research Organizations Vienna, to apply for membership. Website: http://www.iufro.org. It has pledged with â€œBillion Trees Campaignâ€™ to plant 50,000 medicinal plants during the 2009 rainy season. ARCC is endeavoring to establish a good English Medium School for Chenchu children with a view for providing best quality education. Before I conclude my submission, I humbly submit that ARCC is seeking several ways to promote Environment based Sustainable Development of the Chenchus of the Krishna River Valley lest they vanish along with flora and fauna because of their inseparable nature with the Nature.

column24: Activities ASSOCIATION FOR THE PROMOTION OF THE PUPPETRY IN ANDHRA PRADESH (APPA) has been working towards informal education through the art of puppetry and also motivating the children to involve in this art form both for education and infotainment. This art of puppetry is further taken to the next level in the field of education by training the teaching community for its usage in the classroom. Taking one step further we have been effectively using this art form in social empowerment in the subjects of health, hygene, conservation of energy and many major social issues. Also we have been actively involved in propagating various government schemes and taking it to the door step of the beneficiaries in the state of Andhra Pradesh. We have consistently organizing major workshops and seminars through this art form at various centers in India on different social issues and education. We have been making consistent efforts in bringing back the lost glory of leather puppetry in Andhra Pradesh. ACHIEVEMENTS We have successfully designed and distributed around 6000 CRPK in the state of Andhra Pradesh. Successfully carried government schemes, much to the appreciation of Government of Andhra Pradesh. APPA organized A National Puppet Festival in March, 1986 and a Seminar on Educational Puppetry for Young Teachers supported by Sangeet Natak Academy, New Delhi .It had also organized a seminar on Educational Puppetry for Young Teachers, which was supported and funded by the Sangeet Natak Academy, New Delhi. This festival was designed to expose teachers to the idea of adopting puppetry as a classroom tool, and create a platform for a dialogue between traditional and contemporary schools of puppetry. APPA organized Bommalata â€“ 2005. This National Convention on Puppetry, Showcasing Puppetry in Education. In this 3-day National program, different puppeteers participated from all over India. Teachers representing different schools who are using this art form had participated in this event APPA organized in collaboration with Telugu University and Sangeeta Natak Akedemy,NEW DELHI organized Bommalata Utsavâ€“2008, which is a Festival of Puppet Traditions in Andhra Pradesh. In this festival, more then 600 Traditional leather puppeteers participated from all over Andhra Pradesh. In the year 2011 Ministry of Culture has given us the grant, to regain the lost glory in the art of Leather Puppetry in Andhra Pradesh.

column3: ASSOCIATION OF POSITIVE PEOPLE FOR LIVING EXCELLENCE
column21: HIV/AIDS
column24: APPLE is a network or organization formed to address the universal epidemic as HIVAIDS. This organization formed by the PLHIV, for the PLHIV and to the PLHIV. As we know now this epidemic affected the socio economic condition of the families as well as the society. To address this situation in some extent this network established in year 2002 with some the infected people who suffering with the epidemic. With their struggle and experience the members has taken oath to address this issue and to reach the unreached community in this locality. With this affords the organization reached all the community who affected and infected families of West Godavari District of Andhra Pradesh. At this juncture the organization registered 3500 families with consisting of 10000 individuals who are infected with HIV epidemic, out of this nearly 470 children are also there. To address these members the organization approached various Government and International Organizations. Finally the organization got support from Andhra Pradesh State AIDS Control Society (APSCAS), PFI, INP+, TNP+, Family Health International, CAREIndia, Clinton Foundation and VMM etc. The organization closely works with Local Bodies, District Government Administration, Panchayatraj Institutions to leverage the resources and welfare schemes for infected members. With all these support the organization achieved some the following issues which are mile stones for the organization. In Februaryâ€™ 2005 the organization started DIC with the support of APSACS. Through this program the organization address the major health issues for 8000 members. The medical support extended upto March 2008, after that the organization made convergence with the local government health institutions like Area Hospitals, Community Health Centers, Primary Health Centers and Subcenters to leverage the better institutional care and medical care. In Juneâ€™2005 the organization started Access to Care and Treatment (ACT) with the support of Globule fund through PFI, INP+, and TNP+. Through this program the organization address the major advocacy and ART Issues for more then 4000 members. The major achievement is that the organization has effectively addressed the ART adherence, Nutrition Counseling and reduces the Lost to Followup cases. In Septemberâ€™2005 the organization started Parent to Prevention Child to Transmission (PPTCT) out reach services. With this activity the organization ensured the ANC, PNC+ followup, instructional deliveries, MB pair Nevirapine administration and 18 months baby followup. The organization succeeded to reduce the mother to child infection from 2.5 to 1.2 percent in entire district. In Novemberâ€™ 2006 the organization started AVAHAN program with the support of Bill & Milanda Gates Foundation (BMGF). Through this program the organization provided awareness at industrial areas and advocates them to make the work place policies. In Februaryâ€™2008 the organization started the comprehensive support and care program called Balasahyoga with the support of FHI, Clinton Foundation and CAREIndia. With this program the organization working with 3000 families who have children with infected or affected. With this program the organization provided a comprehensive package of services like Testing, Health, Education, Nutrition, Livelihoods, Food Security, Psycho Social Support, ART adherence and followup, leveraging government programs in all the aspects. In this program the organization working with family as a unit. Through this program we reached the families with sustainable and quality solutions to strengthen the family in all aspects. The strength of the organization is Advocacy and Convergence. Through this strategy we leverage all the services and linkages with the government programs to address the major issues of the families. In this context we provided Skill Development Training Programs to Women members and youth members and linked with financial institutions for strengthen their livelihoods.

column24: APARD currently works with 6523 families and continues to strive to improve the lives of the poorest in the drought affected areas. APARD has been primarily working in the drought prone western and southern parts of Kurnool District for enhancement of livelihoods of the poor using participatory processes. APARD has been actively promoting and strengthening various peoplesâ€™ institution for different interventions. These institutions include User Groups, Self Help Groups, VOs, Water Users Associations, Sub Committees, distribution committees, seed bank committees, lift irrigation societies etc. In 2001, APARD took responsibility of implementing IV batch watershed programme in Devanakonda Mandal PIA under adverse situations and developed them as model watersheds in the District. This led to the adoption of APRLP approach and process in non-APRLP watersheds also. A seed bank with high yielding variety seeds was established in the watershed village of Karivemula with a focus for increasing productivity in rainfed areas. This has received wide accolades including Agriculture Minister. In addition to the above programmes, APARD has been working for women empowerment, nutrition, Social Forestry, Horticulture, Youth empowerment, Skill Development, Agree Business and Marketing, Water and Sanitation, Sustainable Agriculture, Veterinary Health camps etc. in 243 villages of Kurnool, Kadapa, Prakasam and Anantapur districts.

column21: HIV/AIDS
column24: Our Trust has organized Legal awareness programme at Hiyath nagar R.R. District. It organized motivation of their Rights. A sensitization camp on Human rights was organized on this day. The meeting was addressed by Senior Civil Advocate Jaya pradha , Hiyath nagsar Some of the local gentlemen attended the programme and addressed about all the right of women. All the Trust members took active participation in this program. They were enabled to work out strategy for effectively preventing crime against women and to evolve strategy for networking among different agencies for combating crime against women. In the Present days so of the poor and middle clears people are becoming and attracted towards intoxication with drugs, alcoholic drinks, and other stuffs like Ganja, Booting, Brown sugar, heroinet marphiya and pethe drire. When the poor and especially the youth (boys and girls) attracted towards drugs as they get them at cheaper price. Even in the richer people keep up the false prestige and culture they were pulled to the den of darkness and dip them in intoxication by some evil minded people for their personal benefits and destroy the innocent people. Due to this intoxication thousands and lakhs of crored pathies and lakhpathies have fallen on roads. At this stage we can simply imagine the condition of poor people who earn on daily wages and how their families are suffering. Daily we are hearing and reading about the suicide only due to financial problems. To educate the innocent poor people and the youth we are regularly conducting counseling in the slum are as and industrial labour colonies for the prevention of alcoholism and drug abuse we have appointed five councilors whose job is to go round the detailed areas and canvas for the prevention of alcoholism and drug abuse. Our Mahila Mandali has also taken up the process of bringing awareness to Self Help Groups through financial institutions. There has been a good response from the Self Help Groups. An awareness camp has been held to educate the loaning habits of the groups and its systems. This year we have conducted meetings and door to door visits by our women volunteers to educate the poor women who are living below the poverty line and encourage them for small savings by forming small groups for benefit and their emergency need. Each group will consists of ten to fifteen members and elect two group leaders among them for maintains, bank transaction and monthly collection. Each group members meet once in a month and decide the member who needs the loan the in that months. The group leaders will take responsibility of recovery of the in small regular instatements with reasonable interest. . This programme has involved women members in the village and they were given training in food processing, packing and storage aspects. Those women were also given information on the economic aspects of this programme and the importance and the place of food processing and packing . They were also information that they can avail loan facility from banks, if they up this activity on a commercial base. We have formed the weaker section of the village into Self Help Groups. They have been trained in savings and credit management so that they will enable themselves into self reliant and self-supportive. They will get an opportunity to get leans form their own group saving at low interest , so that they will be free from the clutches of moneylenders. They are trained in leadership and maintaining proper accounting system. They have been developed linkages with banks so that they can increase their living standards with mutual trust and away from depending on others. We have arranged a short-stay home for girls and women who face the family problems and come out for resettlement. The home can accommodate thirty beneficiaries. We have arranged for under going skilled training in different skills at their own cost. At this home we provide free stay, health care, security and guidance for resettlement. During the year eighty-seven women were be benefited by incoming and out gone beneficiaries. For the welfare of the street children, the organization has taken up a drive to identify the uncared street children. They have been persuaded and then joined in the childrenâ€™s home In all 25 children were benefited under this programme. The organization has provided them with cloths, slippers, hair oils and other materials of sanitary requirement. They were given medical treatment for simple ailments before before being joined in the children homes.

column24: AWARENESS PROGRAM ON MUSLIM MINORITY WELFARE SCHEMES:- We have conducted this program in M.P.P. School for the benefit of Minority people. Four hundred women participated in this program. Z.P. CHAIRPERSON Mr. Suresh Babu, DISTRICT MINORITY WELFARE OFFICERS Mr. Mahaboob Khan, Mr. Sapthagiri, Mrs. Azra Parveen, MPL. COUNCELLOR, Mrs. Subadra Bai, Nursing Superintendent attends the program. Z.P. Chairman given suggestions to the women about welfare schemes, Mr. Mahaboob Khan explained the welfare schemes for the Muslims and Christians. RELIEF AND REHABILITATION FOR FLOOD VICTIMS: - Due to heavy floods occurred Kadapa District in the month of 16th October 2001 and the many of people lost their movable and immovable assets and lives also. Some thousands of families became as shelter less and crops were damage by the effect of floods. BCLDS provided food, drinking water, milk as well as medicine for diseases to the flood victims for 5 days more than 100 families has been survived under this programme. Mr. Suresh Babu, Z.P. Chairperson along with M.D.O. Mr. Subbi Reddy visited this shelter and appreciates our organization work. BLOOD DONATION CAMP: - BCLDS have participated blood donation camp 1st October 2003 which did the AIDS Control Society, Seven youth volunteers and chief functionary of BCLDS have donated blood on behalf of BCLDS. THE DISTRICT COLLECTOR, Velugu PROJECT DIRECTOR, Dist., coordinator, NEHRU YUVAK KENDRA, other distinguished persons participated in the programme. FORMATION OF CEMENT LINK ROAD: - BCLDS has formed cement link road in Chemmumiahpet village, Kadapa mandal with assistance of MANDAL PRAJA PARISHAD GRANTS (A.P. GOVERNMENT), Kadapa Mandal under food for work. Now the people were feeling comfortable. VITAMIN â€˜Aâ€™ DISTRIBUTION: - The free eye camp for children organized by the BCLDS, diagnose the children with help of qualified eye specialist and distributed Vitamin-A capsules with the help of SIGHT AND LIFE, SWITZERLAND to control the eye diseases and blindness among children. More than 1000 children examined in three times and utilized this opportunity. Z.P. VICE-CHAIRMAN Mr. Ravindranatha Reddy inaugurated this program and explains how to prevent eye diseases. Dr. Pradeep Kumar, EYE SPECIALIST diagnoses the children with his staff. ADULT LITERACY PROGRAMME: - We are conducted Adult Literacy Programme (2003-04 =150 learners, and 2004-2006 = 300 learns in Anantapur District) in five villages of Kadapa Mandal and C.K. Dinne Mandal with financial assistance of SEVA BHARAT, SECUNDERABAD, A.P. INDIA. The purpose of the programme is eradicating of illiteracy and brings 100% literacy in target villages. More than 60% of the women are able to write their signatures and few of the women are able to read and write. Out of five centers (30 x 5 = 150) four centers literacy centers learners have started self-help groups opened joint account in the local banks and continuing the programme. This program inaugurated by local M.L.A. DR. KHALEEL BASHA. A.P. MAST, DFID, ACTION AID was conducted training programme on Participatory Poverty Assessment. The BCLDS Chief Functionary participated in the training program. Further, we have PPA in two urban slums of Kadapa Municipality.

column24: Our organizations presence in rural development, human resource and natural resources development are as follows; we associated in the promotion of Andhra Pradesh Government promoted Primary Education Awareness program for children enrolment, helped in associating campaigning HIV/AIDS awareness. Extended participation in the recent events of AP Governments â€œBadibattaâ€ program in attracting young children enrolment into regular schools. We fitted into support 35 school children at Adivipalli village Government School distributed note books/school uniforms in support of children schooling. National Environmental awareness campaign support of Ministry of Environment and Forest-New Delhi being Swarapa Nishata Asharama Philosophical Welfare Society being the nodal agency for the program. Irrigation bore well program in 19 hamlets, one drinking water bore well were implemented, Vermicompost development program for rural farmers/households implemented in 6 hamlets with 50 beneficiaries program sanctioned by CAPART- Hyderabad southern region office. We associated with District Nehru Yuva Kendra centre in finding sports items distributed at our Penumur and Puthalapattu Mandal hamlets. We sourced over seas funds in supplying school going children support program, distributed 175 bi-cycles among Tribal/Dalit children in Penumur Mandal hamlets, including support to 100 tribal women engaged in cutting and arranging dates tree thatch into broom stick for which 5 power operated plastic injection molding machines were given free in manufacturing of plastic handles to the brooms women make. This is an income generation program made inroads into the distant hamlets helping in new way has led to sustenance of income level supported by Erach Roshan Sadri Foundation â€“ (ERSF)-UK. Currently our organization is under active consideration of CAPART for the next phase program in the area of rural income generation program which will lead to different skill training program implemented for the benefit of our target area people. In brief sewing and embroidery skill training to rural women, electrical motor rewinding/repair training to boys/girls, Candle/Incense stick making, Food leaf stitching and beyond for rural educated boys and girls training cell phone servicing program has been chalked out. We associate working with down trodden communitiesâ€™ dalit/indigenous communities across Puthalapattu, Penumur, Gangadara Nellore, Sri Rangarajapuram Mandals. Our intervention among the Dalit and Tribal people welfare program has turned out to bring results which have become an issue and we are getting calls from other caste hamlets and those not or adopt them into our program. This is in relation to children issued bicycles that leading to children putting effort in their studies and scoring good mark is one and another is women helped for their hand skill turning out broom sticks from thatch, additionally women were given working capital support to 200 women and plastic handle making plastic injection molding machines 5 no which has led to women finding enough income generation is another issue among other communities. In this scenario our interventions has caused envy and eye sore to others, we receive positive comments and get comments that is hard also as our development initiations lead us to do just program that dalit and tribal need them.

column21: HIV/AIDS
column24: Ourâ€™s is a voluntary organisation, based at Tuni in East Godavari District of Andhra Pradesh. We are mainly concentrated on women & girl children. Recently completed a programme on girl children, supported by Govt. of India, New Delhi for the previous period, we are working with 1200 sex workers on HIV/AIDS prevention program with the help of Andhra Pradesh State Aids control society (APSACS), Hyderabad, NACO, New Delhi. We determined to change their lives to pull out from the sex work and mingle them into National streamline to lead a respectable life and to save society. In view of that, conducted series of meetings with sex workers shared their feelings. Out of 1200 sex workers only 98 sex workers accepted to stop the trafficking and ready to take up entrepreneur-ship. Formed those 98 sex workers into 10 groups. We encourage them for thrift activity for their future. They followed it and doing thrift since 8 months. They elected their group heads among them to look after cash transactions and to speak on behalf of group. We took it as a challenge task and looking forward for a kind hearted funding agency interested in this aspect.
