column24: THE ORGANISATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE YEAR 1991 WITH A AIM TO PROVIDE QUALITY SKILLED DEVELOPMENT TRAINING AND PROVIDING JOB ORIENTED SKILLED TRAINING IN COMPUTER HARDWARE/SOFTWARE, TYPEWRITING, TAILORING, ZIGZAG, CALLCENTRE & BPO TRAINING TO THE EDUCATED UNEMPLOYED YOUTH OF BOTH SEX IRRESPECTIVE OF CASTE AND CREED. IN THE ABOVE SAID TRADES WITH PLACEMENT FACILITY. ACTIVITES: 1 VOCATIONAL TRAINING IN COMPUTER HARDWARE, SOFTWARE, NETWORKING, CALLCENTRE, BPO. 2 EMEDIAL COACHING FOR CLASS IX,X,INTER I and IIYR. 3 YPEWRITING LOWER and HIGHER GRADE 4 ZIGZAG, TAILORING 5 MOULANA AZAD UPPER PRIMARY SCHOOL UPTO PRIMARY LEVEL, PROPOSED TO CONVERT INTO HIGH SCHOOL. 6 PUBLIC LIBRARY WITH ACADEMIC,COMPETATIVE,TECHICAL EDUCATION, PERIODICALS, DAILY NEWSPAPERS, HISTORY AND LITERATURE AND REFERENCE BOOKS. ACHIEVEMENTS IN THE YEAR 2007 and 08 DEPARTMENT OF YOUTH SERVICES GOVTOFA.P HAD SPONSERED 265 CANDIDATES IN DIFFERENT TRADES OF COMPUTER HARDWARE, SOFTWARE, NETWORKING, CALLCENTRE TRAINING ETC AFTER SUCCESSFULL COMPLETION THE ORGANISATIN HAS PLACED 195 plus CANDIDATES IN DIFFERENT LOCALCOMPANIES AND MNCs. IN THE YEAR 2008 and 09 DEPARTMENT OF YOUTH SERVICES GOVT OF A.P HAD SPONSERED 400 CANDIDATES IN DIFFERENT TRADES OF COMPUTER HARDWARE, SOFTWARE, NETWORKING, CALLCENTRE ETC AFTER SUCCESSFULL COMPLETION THE ORGANISATIN HAS PLACED 280 plus CANDIDATES IN DIFFERENT LOCALCOMPANIES AND MNCs. SINCE 1991 TO TILLDATE THE ORGANISATION HAD BENEFITED ABOUT 7200 plus CANDIDATES BY PROVIDING THEM FREE TRAINING TO GOVT SPONSERED CANDIDATES AND BY CHARGING NOMINAL FEES FOR NONSPONSERED CANDIDATES. APART FROM THIS THE ORGANISATION HAD TAKENUP VARIOUS ACTIVITIES FOR THE UPLIFTMENT OF WEAKER SECTIONS OF THE SOCIETY ESPECIALLY WOMENS BY PROVIDING THEM FREE VOCATIONAL TRAINING AND DIRECT LOANS FROM N.M.D.F.C, NEWDELHI, SCHOLARSHIPS FOR GIRL STUDENTS FROM M.A.E.F NEWDELHI. APART FROM THIIS THE SOCIETY IS RUNNING SENIOR TEACHERS ACADEMY WHEREIN EXPERTS IN DIFFERENT FACULTIES ARE BEING ENGAGED TO GIVE COACHING TO POOR STUDENTS WHO ARE APPEARING FOR VARIOUS BOARD EXAMS. THE ABOVE SAID ACTIVITES ARE RUNNED BY THE ORGANISATION ON NOPROFIT AND NOLOSS BASIS. THE SAID ORGANISATION IS A NONPROFITABLE SERVICE ORGANISATIION WITH AN ESTEEMED OUTSTANDING OF ABOUT 18YRS SERVICES.

column24: B.C.T.Trust is a non-profitable, non-religious, non-political voluntary service organization.It was christened as Bharath Computers Technology Trust in the year 1997.Since then it has been doing a yeomans service to the under privileged and the deprived.(1)General Awareness Programme in Computers:-taking the development in computer applications a awareness programme was conducted for unemployed youth in urban slums and sub-urban areas.The programme was attended by the officials, local leaders.(2)Various vocational Training:-is being imparted to the women of BPL various programmes.(3)Yoga Training.(4)National Festivals:-like 26th Janurary,15th August, Vivekananda Jayanthi, Amberdkar Vardanthi etc are celebrated to develop patriotism amongst the younger generation.(5)International Womens day.(6)Self helf groups promotion and micro-credit finance:-Formation of women thrift group is one of th major achievements of B.C.T.T Groups are being promoted sucessfully with the aim of saving and credit programmes among poor women of different cultures and social motive. Under this programme around 250 self help groups were formed.(7)A programme on "Quality of life" was conducted to the members of self help groups with the help of Central Board for Worker education.Government of India.(8)The SHGs are promoted with following objectives:-Building collective strength of women through promoting of SHGs .To integrate women in the main stream of crdit delivery menhanism and enable then to be self reliant.(9)Health Awareness Porgrammes:- Health awareness programme was cnducted with around two hundred women in which the Field Pubicity Officer from Doordarshan Government of India were participated in it.(10) Family Planning Awareness programmes:-The above programme was conducted to educate the advantages of a small and happy family.The women advised to take care of health and disadvantages of not following family planning methods.The participants for the programme were Dr.A.Prameela and Dr.Madhuri.(!!)Aids Awareness programmes:-Almost importance is given to programmes of Aids. The people in the slums are unaware of the repercussions of the disease,total concentration was laid educate the illiterates and especially the drivers of the motor field.(!2)Training in strong of Fruits and Vegetables.(13)Legal Awareness Programmes:-Legal Awareness programmes to eduate the women folk were conducted.Marriage Laws ,Divorce Laws, Porperty related problems are discussed in awareness programmes.etc...

column24: Since inception, we have been assisting women and men in their struggle against economic backwardness, discrimination, exploitation and atrocities. We have made some progress towards the empowerment of poor and marginalized women and men, brining equality and financial independence. The Chief Functionary, EC Members, Staff and Volunteers of the organization have attained a good experience in organizing health-education-environment awareness campaigns, community mobilization, organization of people, motivation of target people etc. We work with downtrodden like SC, ST, and OBC etc. We gained good insight in conducting welfare and development programs for the benefit of poor and needy. Ever since inception, we are endeavoring in implementing various need based interventions as follows: 1. Social Engineering Activities of Lift Irrigation 2. SHGs Promotion and Formation Of MACTS 3. Vermi Compost, Awareness Program, 4. Communal harmony, Peace 5. Family Counseling and Domestic Violence 6. NPM AND ORGANIC FARMING 7. Flood Response programme 8. Village profile and PRA 9. column24: Byrraju Foundation is a not for profit organization committed to transforming the quality of life of the rural underprivileged. It seeks to build progressive and self reliant rural communities, adopting a holistic approach. Since inception in July 2001, the Foundation has been relentlessly addressing rural needs and running numerous services in Healthcare, Sanitation, Safe Drinking Water, Education, Disability Rehabilitation and Empowerment, Adult Literacy, Women Empowerment and providing training in Livelihood skills for both men and women. It also has technology driven programs like community media projects, Tele Medicine, and Virtual Agri advice through its Aswini (Virtual Delivery of Services) platform. It is the first not for profit organization to adopt six sigma as the core management framework for designing new processes and making breakthrough improvements to existing processes. Six-Sigma focuses on customer (beneficiary) centricity, process orientation, metrics and continuous improvement. The large volume of the Foundations operations lends itself to the Six Sigma way of working. The challenge at all times however, is to keep it simple and demystified so that ultimately the rural communities may themselves be able to use these modern and useful techniques. As of today, it runs more than 40 major programmes in each of the 200 adopted villages spread across East Godavari, Guntur, Krishna, Ranga Reddy, Visakhapatnam and West Godavari districts of Andhra Pradesh, impacting 3 million rural lives. Application of the best management practices, technology and constant innovation are its key differentiators. Its mission is to create the largest global platform for holistic and sustainable rural transformation comprising many like minded partners and processes that are innovatively designed combining global best practices, effective management systems and state of the art technology. It measures over 1800 real-time metrics for effective monitoring of its rural transformation programs.

column24: Christian Association for Medicalmission and Peoplesdevelopment (CAMP) a non-profit Organization, Committed to the cause of the poor and marginalized in the rural and urban poor areas of Tribal and fisher communities of Guntur District. The objective of the organization is to work for facilitating the poor to rise from poverty and vulnerability through self-help and collective action towards improvement of their environment, livelihood patterns and proper prioritization of their lives. The CAMP initiative was started in Ponnur, Guntur District in 1990, by a team of committed individuals drawn together by their concern for the deplorable conditions of Tribalâ€™s & fisher folk residing along the seacoast in forest areas of Guntur district. Today CAMP has done commendable work in its fifteen odd years of existence, and has expanded its activities both in terms of geographical and functional areas. The organization has also remained loyal to its initial target group, the fisher folk, and has stood by them during the most destructive episode in their community life, the Tsunami of 2004, and has done pioneering work to help the community regain its normal functioning. Registered under XXI of 1860 societies Act- 393/1992, also having FCRA registration No. 010190227. The organization is exempted from Income Tax under Section 12A. The strength of the organisation is the staffs that have professionalism as well as commitment towards vulnerable communities, the recent support through Plan International (India) and CARE India emphasised on focusing on women and children with emphasis on rural development through promotion of sustainable livelihoods. The coordinated efforts have enhanced convergence between government programs and CAMP programs to avoid duplication of activities, which enabled organisation to become members of various advisory committees by district Administration. Organisation is technically strong in Participatory methods and Capacity buildings extended its technical expertisation to other peer organisations in the district. However organisation has membership in the networks Like CADME to put collaborative efforts to ensure rural development.

column24: Broad category of activities taken up by the organization.Work with traditional groups like fisher-folk, Tribal in livelihood and environment management and development, and disaster preparedness. Organization of beneficiaries especially women into SHGs, Thrift & Credit, and micro entrepreneurial groups. Organizing communities for their own development to ensure community owned rural development. Health initiatives including Reproductive and Child Health & HIV/AIDS. Child interventions including mainstreaming of child labor and management of Early Child Development centers. Water and Sanitation initiatives including Desiltation of tanks, construction of surface tanks, construction of sanitation units, and transportation of waster to scarce areas. Disaster relief and rehabilitation activities including Tsunami response & rehabilitation Strength of the organization: The strength of the organisation is the staffs that have professionalism as well as commitment towards vulnerable communities, the recent support through Plan International (India) and CARE India emphasised on focusing on women and children with emphasis on rural development through promotion of sustainable livelihoods. The coordinated efforts have enhanced convergence between government programs and CAMP programs to avoid duplication of activities, which enabled organisation to become members of various advisory committees by district Administration. Organisation is technically strong in Participatory methods and Capacity buildings extended its technical expertisation to other peer organisations in the district. However organisation has membership in the networks Like CADME to put collaborative efforts to ensure rural development. List of activities taken up by the organization till date On going and Completed Projects Completed Projects Community Based Disaster Preparedness Programme with support of OXFAM GB the project was implemented in 5 villages and 150 youth were trained as Task Force Group Members with 50% of women. T.B Awareness Project T. B Awareness meetings were organized in Ponnur, Bapatla, Kakumanu and Nizampatnam Mandals of Guntur districts with the support of World Vision India, Guntur. For Women thrift cooperative societies, students, public, Govt PHC staff, Private Medical Practitioners and Anganwadi workers.Environmental Awareness Campaign With the support of Ministry of Environment and Forest, Govt of India through Deccan development society, Hyderabad. CAMP organized awareness programmes on Water and its importance and Solid waste Management in Ponnur and Kakumanu Mandals of Guntur District. Scientific Awareness Project. In Collaboration with Dept of Science and technology Govt of India through CERENA Foundation, Hyderabad, CAMP organized awareness programmes through cultural performances in Ponnur and Nizampatnam Mandals of students and public on â€œ Science and its Importance.Global Movement for Children. In collaboration with Plan International (India) CAMP organized Global Movement on HIV/ AIDS with children in Ponnur, Nizampatnam, Kothapalem and Kuchanapudi of Guntur District. Community Micro Projects on Livelihood Restoration & Stabilization CARE India Chennai is supporting this project in the Tsunami affected Coastline Mandals of Guntur District. CAMP in Nizampatnam, P.V. Palem and Repalle Mandals covered 10 Villages. Women Cooperative Programme. 95 Women Thrift Cooperatives were formed in 95 villages of Guntur, Prakasam and West Godavari Districts with the membership of 8157. Since 2001 Cooperative Development Foundation, Warangal is supporting the Programme. Ongoing Projects Combating Child labor in coastal Andhra Pradesh project In collaboration with PLAN International, Hyderabad. CAMP initiated the Project in 5 villages of Nizampatnam Mandal of Guntur District. Women Empowerment Programme (MF) In collaboration with CARE India CAMP initiated the Programme in 95 villages of Guntur and West Godavari districts of AP. Promotion of Safe Water and Sanitation (WATSAN) Programme In collaboration with CARE India CAMP initiated the project in 4 villages of Nizampatnam and Repalle Mandals of Guntur District the project comprises of Hard Ware and Soft Ware components. Micro Leasing and Micro Service Centre (Livelihood Project): In collaboration with CARE India, CAMP is implementing Livelihood project in 3 villages of Nizampatnam Mandal. The project emphasizes on Promotion of Community assets, Net Bank, OBM Clinics, Input bank for the fisher folk families. Micro Insurance Programme In collaboration with CARE India, CAMP is implementing Micro Insurance programme in 95 villages of Guntur district. The project is intended to develop risk coping mechanism during disasters and accidents.

column24: CARVE Brief note on Activities and achievements Activities 1) Participatory Resource Appraisal (PRA) & Participatory Resource Mapping (PRM) for situational analysis 2) Community sensitized programs in habitation level 3) Resource Inventory for different project related for natural resource management, livelihood, sanitation and health projects. 4) Organize kalajathas for awareness creation 5) Trainings in measuring rain fall, water levels 6) Capacity building trainings for different community based institutions 7) Gender main streaming trainings on natural resource management 8) Book keeping trainings for different CBOs. 9) Create awareness for school children on natural resource management 10) Exposure visits on different development activities. 11) Participatory Technology Development (PTD) 12) Integrated pest management (IPM) 13) Farmer Water School (FWS), Farmer field school (FFS) 14) Soil and water quality analysis for irrigation and awareness 15) Drinking water quality analysis and awareness creation 16) Constructions of artificial Ground water recharge structures and water shed programmes. 17) Crop Water Budget (Water Balance estimation) exercises (CWB) 18) Trainings on organic fertilizers and pesticides 19) Linkage development between village level stake holders and government departments 20) Skills and knowledge upgrade trainings and workshops for habitation level artisans. Achievements â€¢ About 3000 farmer families are capable of measuring groundwater levels and rainfall by using scientific equipment â€¢ About 3000 farmer families are able to understand the availability of ground water in their HU (Hydrological Unit/Water shed). â€¢ 90% of farmers in the 75 habitations have been adopted water Use efficiency methods like Drip, Sprinklers, and Mulching and piped irrigation for their crops. â€¢ In 13 hydrological units 80% of farmers are practiced less water consumption crops instead of paddy in rabi season based on the available ground water availability â€¢ 675 farmers belongs to 75 habitations are capable to address ground water issues in their hydrological units before district and state level forums â€¢ 3000 farmers were graduated (2006-2008) through FWS-FMGS and received certificates from APFAMGS / FAO â€¢ About 150 farmers have got capacity as farmer facilitators (2006-2008) through FWS-FMGS â€¢ About 1500 farmers are trained in collecting soil & water samples for soil and water quality testing. â€¢ About 2500 farmers are using vermi compost for their crops replacing chemical fertilizers. â€¢ About 950 farmers adopted IPM (integrated pest management) practices in 75 habitations. â€¢ In 70 habitations, farmers have knowledge on Bio products and its benefits. â€¢ 630 childrenâ€™s both boys and girls have knowledge on PHM (participatory hydrological monitoring) activities. â€¢ 1250 farmers are supported and practicing backyard kitchen gardening. â€¢ 68 GMCâ€™s (groundwater monitoring committees) conducted study on food and nutrition, and now they have full knowledge on their food and nutrition status. â€¢ About 85 farmers are using Tricoderma viridy for their Sweet Orange Orchards, which was learned through Participatory Technology Development (PTD) processes. â€¢ Farmers belongs to 75 (GMCs) habitations developed good relationship with govt. departments and got benefit with different govt. schemes. Several programs worth of rupees 88,80,000/- have been mobilized from agriculture, horticulture, Irrigation & RWS departments. â€¢ 13 hydrological Unit Networks (HUNs) have been registered with Govt. as societies under societies registration act. These registered bodies started functioning on their own. â€¢ Farmers successfully executed the construction of AGRs (Artificial Ground water Recharge structures). This activity results an additional recharge of 4 lakh cu. Meters of water into aquifers. â€¢ Farmers contributed/mobilized an amount of Rs. 25,000 to manage water bodies in future. â€¢ About 60 people belongs to pottery community were trained in advance practices of pottery.

column24: The organisations focus is children and people of the underpriveleged sections of the society by providing them oppurtunities for basic education and helping them to acquire social skills for improving their living standards by using arts and media as tools. column24: Major Activities and Achievements â€¢Facilitated a Personal Relation ship centers at the government hospitals for easing the process of delivering medial certificate to the persons with disabil-ities. â€¢Initiated Grievance Help Desk Centers for forwarding grievance of the persons with disabilities to the district collector for perusal. â€¢Organized workshop with APIDC, chairman to provide opportunities of jobs in private and corporate sectors. â€¢200 land and houses have been sanctioned for the persons with disabilities in Kandi Village of Sanga Reddy through constant lobby with the officials and the Honorable Chief Minister of the State. â€¢30 Residential Quarters for the Persons with disabilities, running telephone boots on pavements, has been sanctioned under VAMBY schemes of the gov-ernment at Sherilingampally through constant advocacy and lobby with the Member of Parliament, Secunderabad constituency and Municipal Corpora-tion authorities. â€¢150 Tri-cycles and wheel chairs have been distributed with the support of LANCO LIGHT Trust to the PWDs.â€¢Established Vocational Training Center for women with disability grossly benefited 350 women. â€¢Organized a District Level Sports meet for the Persons with disabilities, to mark the occasion of International Disabled Day. 280 persons with disabilities have been participated. â€¢Facilitated and performed Inter-Caste, Inter-Disability marriages of 37 poor couples.  â€¢Organized a Human Chain involving 1116 in Medak, Ranga Reddy and Khamam District for campaigning on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities on the occasion of International Human Rights day. â€¢Organized 300 Persons with disabilities from 2 districts to participation in a CHALO DELHI CAMPAIGN, for giving representation to the government on effective implementation of the PWD Act. â€¢Organized rally and workshop with the Public Telephone Booth owners on the hike of Public call rates involving 1000 members. As a result the BSNL has withdrawn its  proposal to hike the rated of Public call booths. â€¢ 360 Unemployed youth suffering with various disabilities have been sup-ported to access livelihoods for enhancing their living standards. â€¢ Organized workshops and seminars on NREGA Act, Right to Information Act for the youth, public representatives and activists. â€¢Provided educational support for the 45 students belonging to SC, ST and other poor families.

column3: CENTRE FOR EMPOWERMENT AND DEVELOPMENT OF WOMEN
column21: Health & Family Welfare
column24: Winner of World Bankâ€™s India Development Market place IDM 2004 projects competition, one of the 20 winners out of 1500 projects that were submitted from all over India with an award of 20,000 $ for the project titled Adolescent girls as promoters of basics in feminine hygiene, health and nutrition in the year 2004 and was implemented from july 2004 to june 2005 and was later recognized as one of the best 5 implemented projects out of the 20 winners of IDM 2004 in the year 2008 . A paper prepared by Dr.Aluri Vijayalakshmi on the concept, implementation and results of the project was accepted for presentation in the XVI FIGO World congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists held at koulalumpur, Malasia, in Nov.2006. Target audience was school going and out of school adolescent girls, 12-16 years age, of low socioeconomic status and women in urban slums and rural areas. Created awareness to more than 10,000 adolescent girls on reproductive and sexual health, nutrition and hygiene. Lack of health information, Poverty and lack of adequate free Govt. services are road blocks for their good health Hygienic practices and eating habits of adolescent girls have improved. Adolescent girls were motivated to delay their sexual activity, marry after 18 years of age and have their first child birth 2 years later. Adolescent girls and women are empowered with the basic knowledge of their reproductive and sexual health and encouraged to have safe sexual practices. Trained 185 lady teachers, 50 women volunteers of Sri Satya Sai organization, 25Yuva Acharyas of Art of Living Asram, Banglore, and 25 Preraks of Adult education Dept.,EG.Dt., who in turn were motivated to create awareness to adolescent girls in their area of work. Provided free Ob. services to about 2000 and free delivery services including cesarean operations to about 500 and family planning surgeries to 50 Adolescent girls and women. Standard Ob. Care, free of cost, is accessed by poor women with almost nil morbidity and mortality and with dignity, and with nil hassles to wait for longer periods and missing their work. Provided training in tailoring, embroidery, Fashion technology, soft toys making ,darning, zariwork, fabric painting, type writing- higher and lower, beautician course, repair of home appliances, Accountancy etc., enabling the trainees to be self reliant and CEDOW is also acting as a facilitator to acquire employment opportunities. About 1500 women and adolescent girls are benefitted Conducted seminars and workshops on issues like Gender bias, Gender Violence, Development of women, Govt. programs and N.G.O. involvement, Empowerment of women, Status of Women in the new millennium, Present scenario of education of girls etc and also on health topics like menopause, common skin problems and preventive and treatment aspects, chronic backache in women, Diabetes, burns, STIs/HIV/AIDS etc. Providing free legal counseling and aid for poor women who are harassed and abandoned women and also providing them shelter for short time. Giving scholarships to 10-30 students of Govt. high schools, Polytechnics and degree colleges per year for the past few years

column24: CPFâ€™s accomplishments over the past five years can be summarised below under three major areas: 1. Participatory Forest Management CPF came into existence with its work on participatory forest management, which was initiated with involvement in the Joint Forest Management in 1996 when CPF was part of CWS. In Andhra Pradesh, CPF could reach out to 680 Vana Samrakshana Samithis (VSSs) belonging to 32 forest ranges in 12 districts of Andhra Pradesh through 32 local partner NGOs. These VSSs have 80,800 households and take care of 1.5 lakh ha of forest area in their charge. CPF through partner NGOs provided capacity building to these VSSs in microplan preparation, review and revision, Gender sensitisation and mainstreaming, resolution of various kinds of conflicts, facilitation skills to the partner NGO functionaries, policy and practice change processes, collaborations in livelihood enhancement, engagement with the forest department, community empowerment processes and mainstreaming concerns of HIV/AIDS. Recently, CPF has been involved in the Forest Rights Act 2006 both in providing inputs to the draft bill, rules etc and in the process of implementation. 2 Sustainable Livelihoods While working with the Girijan Cooperative Corporation (GCC) on NTFP based livelihoods CPF started to understand the livelihood status of the members of VSSs in the CPF project area. CPFâ€™s initiatives on sustainable livelihoods to the forest dwelling and dependent communities fall in two broad categories, viz. forest produce based and land use based. A third category of finding alternative means to supplement the income is also attempted. Forest produce based interventions are i) Improving the service delivery of the Girijan Cooperative Corporation ii) Value addition to the Adda leaf iii) Sustainable extraction of wild honey As part of land use alternatives initiative, fodder generation and management was taken. Besides fodder development on the common lands, grazing lands earmarked for Panchayats were also reclaimed for fodder development in Mahabubnagar. Embroidery project was initiated with 30 Lambadi women of Narsapur forest range in Medak division. On the request of the Forest Department it was scaled up to five more divisions covering 225 women. 3 Policy Advocacy Significant results achieved by CPF by advocacy are : incorporation of recommendations of stakeholder consultations on CFM conducted by CPF, in the CFM GO and in the Project Implementation Plan of APCFM project, Changes in the R&R policy GO, withholding certain clauses from implementation with regard to the convergence GO (Velugu project), Circular for uniform implementation of CFM GO across the state, 100% returns from beedi leaf to collectors, Micro plan preparation, review of the status of implementation of CFM GO, benefit sharing with communities are some of the accomplishments at State level. At National level, CPF joined campaigns spearheaded by other agencies with regard to Biodiversity Act and Forest Rights Act 2006. It also spearheaded a campaign for the implementation of the Act. CPF has been informing the State level steering committees in Andhra Pradesh and Orissa on the same.

column24: The major activity of the Organisation Watershed Development programmes, Agriculture Development and also we work on Child labour issues, /child Rights, Women Development etc. In Andhra Pradesh majority of people living in Rural areas and there main ocupation is Agriculture. But due to the climate change and the habits of human the rainfall is decreasing day by day. But the Agriculture needs water for good yeild. Because of this problems they are not getting good yeilds and the Farmers getting difficult to surview. Hence the Farmers Sucide cases are happening. To overcome this problem Watershed Development Project is a good solution. By implementing the Waterswhed Project in our experience we have noticied the increase in water table of that perticular area. So we have achivied so many sucessfull results. If water table increases the Agriculture production will also increases. With this the farmers will be happy.

column24: Children Education CRD working in 70 villages of Rolla and Madakasira mandals, and consolidated our interventions in these villages. CRSD continued to ensure that all children complete 10th grade. We focused on English Language Teaching (ELT) as the second language for children of grades 3, 4 and 5 oral and written in the last one year. We have tested a set of materials for government teachers in English for grades 1 and 2. Our work with school not going children, children in schools upto grade 10, improvement of governance through parents proactive involvement, training of government school teachers and advocacy with the government education department about Multi Grade Multi Level methodology has made a good impact in the sector. Women CRSD promoted Adavalla Abhyudaya Sangham, a federation of women self help groups in 3 mdandals of Anantapur district. Through the forum legal aid was provided for the victims of domestic violence and counseling centre was also established to cater the needs. Health The Village Health Workers (VHW) programme is successful in 80 villages. All the 80 women were from local villages and were trained as VHWs. The training covered common reproductive health problems, STDs, nutritional deficiency diseases, tuberculosis, womenâ€™s reproductive health issues, anemia, dehydration, vitamin deficiency and others. HIVAID The campaign included organizing cultural shows, conducting meetings with the Self Help Groups, Youth associations, Womenâ€™s village federations, Gramasabhas etc. Handbills were prepared in simple Telugu, and were distributed to the villagers during these meetings. Dalit empowerment CRSD promoted Dalita Chaitanya Vedika to take up issues under the SC &ST Prevention of Atrocities Act 1989 in Anantapur district. Conducting awareness meetings and trainings for dalits networks and associations as well as taking up cases related to Atrocities were the main activities under dalit empowerment. Budget Advocacy CRSD initiated Citizen-Budget Advocacy work in Andhra Pradesh in 2007 with focus on research & studies in specific budget components, capacity building of NGOs through awareness & trainings and campaign on proper budget allocation for dalits, adivasis and women. CRSD has been involved in sensitizing the social activist groups, networks and political parties on the importance of Budget Analysis from a pro-poor perspective and demanding for better allocations to the poor in Andhra Pradesh. MGNREGS CRSD initiated the process of promotion of wage seekers associations under MGNREGS in four districts of Andhra Pradesh in 250 panchayats. The objective of the wage seekers associations was to build pressure on the administration to demand work under NREGS. The following are the activities of the associations. Watershed Development CRSD implemented 24 watersheds development programmes in 3 mandals, out of which were 10 under APRLP and 3 were under DDP VIII batch and 1 from CAPART. The Rayalaseema Watershed Development Programme (RWDP) which we implemented from 1996 to 2005 was an experimental programme with a focus on gender, dalit, equity and peoples participation with low cost and indigenous technology. We conducted a study in 52 APRLP watersheds as an Internal Resource Organisation (IRO).

column24: Provision of nutritional support nearly 500 children in 10 Mandals of Nellore District. Mobilization of nutrition support to 300 children through conduction of advocacy activities. Formation of Family Support Groups and Child Support groups in 8 Mandals. Provision of Educational Support, Medical Support to 300 children. Providing of Income Generation Programmes to 150 Members infected and affected with HIV/AIDS. Providing Disaster Preparedness Floating aids material to 600 Task Force Members in 20 Villages of Kota, Vakadu and Chillakur Mandals of Nellore District. We have provided subsidy on Fishing material through conducted advocacy with fisheries departments. Promotion of Income Generative activities and 58 are given in target areas for vegetables business, eggs business, groom stick, rangoli powder, iron shop and other petty traders. Conduction of the PLWHAS family training programme on nutrition food and medical care & personal Hygiene. 179 Children are mainstreamed in the regular school. Sensitization classes on HIV/AIDS and Disability to 280 members. Out Boat Motor Repair Training through Workshop to 60 members in out 5 target villages in two terms Skill up gradation training on Seas Shell Artifacts making to 25 members. Issued Identification Cards to the Sea Shell Trainees by Ministry of Textiles, Govt. of India, New Delhi. 80 adolescent girls are got tailoring training programme under vocational training. 35 beneficiaries received revolving fund amount for fish vending under Livelihoods Sea shell Articraft was started in Anjalapuram and Srinivasa Puram villages. Provided Nutrition food to children aged between 2 Â½ to 5 years in our Govindapalli Palem villages of Kota Mandal. 320 adolescent girls have been trained under life skills education 22 pre school children are enrolled in the ECCD center 250 children have become the members in Children clubs and they were supported by sports materials 125 both school going and non school going children got trained in CBDP 60 school children got trained in SBDP 48 preschool children were supported by providing play and educational material 124 school children are benefited by the School Improvement Program (structures, play materials, safe water etc,) 10 school children were supported by Text books under book bank Providing of Computer Training to 35 School Children and 21 Adolescent Children at Thupili Palem Village of Vakadu Mandal of Nellore district. Providing of Village Contingency plan and School Safety Plan in all our target villages Formation of MACTS for fisher folk women in the name of â€œChaitanya Mahila Matyakara Paraspara Sahaya Sahakara Parapathi Sangham Ltdâ€ at Duggaraja Patnam. Provision of Revolving fund amount Rs. 3,00,000 to 5 village 1010 Artisans were identified and ID cards were distributed. 10 Languishing handicrafts were identified during survey (i.e.) Wooden Cutlery, Leather Puppetry, Palm leaf craft, Fabric painting, Sea Shell Artifact, lace work, Zeri embroidery work, Wood carving. 85 Self Help Groups were formed 5 Clusters were formed 4 Mutually Aided Cooperative Societies were formed. 1332 artisans were included under JBY scheme. 200 artisan children were identified and provided educational scholarship. 200 Artisan Credit Cards were provided to the 200 artisans. 560 Insurance Coverage through ICICI bank 140 health Claims were provided through ICICI Bank For 10 artisans having Artisan Credit Cards got Rs.20000/- as loan amount from the Government. column24: 1. CHILD WELFARE PROJECT : A) BALATEJASSU : (An innovative Programme to assist the children in difficult situation) GUNTAKAL is major Railway Junction place where 25-30 passenger trains are regularly passing through Guntakal station every day. We observed that nearly 2-3 children who are ran away from their home with various reasons are get down at Guntakal every day. We are aware that the children are used to beg for food and also became criminals and anti-social elements later on. To prevent these children from bad habits, we are running shelter home at Modinabad, Guntakal. We identify the children in Railway platform and bring them to shelter. Later we enquire about their address of their parents and we handling over them to their parents. During the year 2008-09 we identified 182 ran away children in platform and reunited them to their parents. An amount of Rs. 2,05,338/- was utilized during the year 2008-09. We also conducted De-addiction / Orientation camps for hard core children to change their behaviour and to lead normal life. B) BALAVIKAS : (An innovative Programme for the welfare of children in need of care & protection) The organization running shelter home for the street children who are not having family tieups and are staying at footpaths and Railway platforms. For the welfare of these children. We are providing shelter, food, clothes, medicines, education and life skills. The aim of the project is to withdraw them from streets and footpaths and to provide care and protection for the welfare of these children. During the year 2008-09, 30 street children are admitted in Balavikas. All the children are admitted in School to continue education. During the year 2008-09 an amount of Rs. 85,350/- was utilized and 25 children are with drawn from streets and prevent them to become child labours. 2. MEDICAL & HEALTH PROJECTS : A) Urban Health Centre under A.P. Slum Health care Project (IPP VIII â€“ extension) The organization is running one Urban Health centre at Bhagyanagar slum in GUNTAKAL town by covering 7 slums with 25000 slum population living below poverty line. The organization is providing health care and out reach services particularly in maternal and child health care areas combined with minimum and child health care to make it possible to achieve the goal of health by 2020 among the slum community. An amount of Rs. 3,27,076/- was utilized during the year 2008-09. We achieved the targets of immunization family welfare methods and MMR in the allotted area. B) RCH PROGRAMME : Under RCH-II, we are providing health services at Yellanur Mandal of Anantapur District to improve ANC, acceptance of FP methods, increase of institutional deliveries, treatment of RTI and awareness on age at marriage among adolescent in 12 villages of 3 Sub-Centres. During the year 2008-09 we utilized an amount of Rs. 4,64,681/- to provide health services in Yellanur Mandal. C) RNTC PROGRAMME : The District Collector and Chairman, District TB control society, Anantapur sanctioned Scheme-I and II to Chaitanya Rural Development Society at Guntakal Rural and Urban areas to implement RNTC programmes. Accordingly we appointed 1 Supervisor to assist the programme in Guntakal Mandal. During the year 2008-09, 182 TB cases are diagnosed and provided DOT out of them 65 patients are cured and the remaining patient are under Treatment. We also organized DOT providers training programme for 25 volunteers in Guntakal Mandal. All these volunteers are assisting in providing DOT treatment to the patients. An amount of Rs. 76,595/- was utilized during the year 2008-09. 3. OLD AGE HOME Conducted base line survey to identify the destitute widow women in Chippagiri and in Alur Mandals. We are also providing Shelter, Nutrition and Medical Care for the 50 beneficiaries from 01.01.2008 an Amount of Rs. 1,29,737/- was utilized during the year 2008-09. 4. MID DAY MEALS PROGRAMME : As per the instructions of District Collector, we are providing Nutrition Mid Day Meals for 750 School Children of 6 Municipal Elementary Schools at Guntakal Municipality. Rs. 2,83,437/- was utilized during the year 2008-09. 5. SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT : We are also conducted Awareness programme on Solid Waste Management at Chippagiri Rural of Kurnool Dist. and educated the public, the system of utilizing domestic waste in Agriculture Manner.

column24: Main objective of Chetana Society is to build awareness, consciousness, knowledge, skills and capacities of poor people, especially targeting women, children and youth. It believes that the success of this objective depends on the understanding of the aspirations of the poor. This requires the involvement and participation of the local people, and their representatives. Chetana is associated with the efforts of several individuals who have redeemed themselves in promoting the larger interests of the society. It has been working on environmental issues in Andhra Pradesh and in Hyderabad. In these campaigns, individuals from different walks of life are continuously supporting it: lawyers, doctors, academics, journalists, teachers, etc. It relies also on a strong network of youth, who are poised to set the direction of social change. Personnel presently associated with Chetana have been working on environment and development issues in Andhra Pradesh through various activities and initiatives. Due to them, this organization has enormous experience on issues of pollution and peopleâ€™s struggles associated with industrial pollution. It is dedicated to the concept of sustainable development. Chetana aims to motivate people to organize efforts, which promote environmental preservation, ecological conservation and alternative models of development. Chetana recognised the need to develop awareness and knowledge on agricultural issues for Indian farmers, especially women and disadvantaged sections. Farmers need to be exposed to wider issues, which would enable the Indian society to understand the changing scenarios and the range of choices being developed across the world. Most of the small and marginal farmers are not aware of the implications of policies and decisions, and also the fluctuations in the markets. Market knowledge of these sections has to be improved in order to empower them intellectually to respond to the need for their opinions and decisions. Similarly, it has been working on understanding the Textile chain of production, especially related to cotton. In this chain, Chetana is working on documenting information related to poor handloom weavers and develop a framework for their development. Over years, Chetana has defined its priorities in the following areas: Environmental Pollution and Urban problems Sustainable and equitable development Public Health Promotion of environment-friendly methods and technologies Chetana has also initiated a major programme on handloom sector, which has two distinct approaches: research and policy advocacy, and facilitating production by SHG-led weavers. Chetana has been working on information development and information dissemination on handloom weavers. It has brought out few publications related to women, budgets, cotton, markets, etc., including a regular newsletter. These publications are disseminated to the weavers, civil society and policy makers through workshops, meetings and directly. Chetana has also facilitated the formation of Self-Help Groups of weavers. These SHGs are given training and capacity building in designs, dyeing, book keeping, etc. SHGs also do production with the support of Chetana. SHGs manage their common funds, and help member weavers to earn income through production. This activity intended to reduce poverty among the weavers is mainly concentrated in Nalgonda district, in various villages, near Choutuppal and Pochampally.

column24: Child Care Welfare Society has been working from the year 2006 for the development of the economically weaker sections of Krishna Districts. CCWS is registered under societies Registration Act 35 of 2001, and has IT exemption under 12(A). The organization is well managed and stable with the resources and personal who are capable of undertaking welfare activities. The services of this organization is available to all those who require it, irrespective of caste creed or affiliations. Formed by a group of dedicated persons this organization has been undertaking development projects for the poor and needy belonging to the scheduled castes and scheduled tribes. Under the stewardship of Ms. Srihari Latha the Executive Secretary, this organization has been mainly involved in implementing Health Camps, Domestic Child Labour, Street Childrenâ€™s, Women Welfare Activities and other such activities. We have also taken up Programmes designed to improve the status of women in society to attain gender equality. CCWS has promoted Vocational Training Programmes.

column24: the child foundation of india was established in the year ninteen hundred and ninty with head quarters at visakhapatnam.The organisation was registerd under the societies registration act eighteeh hundred and sixty.the foundation was established to commemorate the birth day centenary celebrations of baba sahed amekbar,the architect of the indian consistution and the saviour of the downtrodden of free india.the society has reputed persons on itts management and advisory committe such as sri.rk ratnam former inspector general of accounts govt of india sri.t.munnivenkatappa ias retd.sri gourinath ifs and several other versatile social workers.the founder president dr.k surya rao is anoted physician known for his dedicated social service for the welfare of the community.it is proud moment to the state thatour organisation bagged national award in child welfare that was received from he the president of india sri kr narayanan art rastrapathibhavan new delhi 2002.also padmasri was awarded to the founder president dr.k surya rao for his oustading contribution in the area of social service and medical reserach in 2008 by he the president of india.every student is given proper counseling indidually by a qualified psycholosist and dr.surya rao who visits the school on a regular schedule to atted on health needs of the inmates.this is enhancing the self confidence competitive spirit and mental harmony of the children.many old students of this school have attained excellence in higher education at college level including medical college and engineering college.three students became doctors and seven students became software engineers and one sub inspector of polce.several students have been placed in high positions in various establishments in india and abroad.

column24: The Trust has been working for the Comprehensive development of persons with Disabilities(PWDs) and implementing Community Based Rehabilitation(CBR) for the last 10 years in 8 mandals of Mahabubnagar District of Andhra Pradesh. The guiding principles of our work are ownership by the PWDs, convergence, compliance with national and international conventions and statutory provisions, livelihood development. The key interventions are 1. Social mobilisation- formation and nurturing of SHGs and their federations 2. capacity building of all stakeholders including government officials and representatives of local Bodies 3. Rehabilitation services under CBR mode 4. Livelihood development 5. Facilitating inclusive policies and programs. Thus we facilitated formation of 305 Self Help Groups and federated them at mandal level. We facilitated rehabilitation services to 6550 people with deisabilities under CBR program. These 8 mandal federations are managing 8 neighbourhood centres for providng CBR services. One special school for the children with Mental retardation and severe disabilities is run by the federations with finacial support from the Government under Rajiv Vidya Mission. We facilitated accessing of Rs. 54.87 lakhs by federations from Government which they use as revolving fund and rotate among themselves for funding their livelihood activities. This is called Community Initiative Fund(CIF) and totally managed by the federations. They could also access Rs. 11.73 lakhs from Commercial Banks as loan for their livelihood activities.

column21: Women's Development & Empowerment
column24: ïƒ˜ COWE was formed the year 2004 by a dedicated group of six successful women entrepreneurs. COWEâ€™s activities commenced from 22nd November 2004. ïƒ˜ From 20 members as on the date of commencement, today the membership is over 500 strong ïƒ˜ Altruism or selfless concern for the well being of women prompted the founders to come together and start the organization. ïƒ˜ All the activities initiated since inception had certain ultimate objectives for the benefit of women as stated below: 1. Develop new women entrepreneurs 2. Economic empowerment of women 3. Enhancing opportunities to women by equipping them with required technical know-how. 4. Develop industrial parks exclusively for women entrepreneurs 5. Guidance to new women entrepreneurs to run their business activities successfully. 6. Guidance and facilitation to obtain institutional finance to new and needy women entrepreneurs 7. Creating opportunities to new entrepreneurs to market their products 8. Assistance to existing small business women / NGOs / artisans / weavers to find new avenues to market their products. 9. Facilitating Micro finance 10. Facilitating women entrepreneurs to interact with overseas organizations 11. Presentations to working women on how to face challenges of work and home. 12. The ultimate objective was to start more industries, more business organizations and create job opportunities, preferably in rural areas. 13. The realization of the above objective is in the national interest and in accordance with our national policies

column24: We are committed to the cause of improved quality of life of weaker sections and the vulnerable who are poor, exploited and challenged in the context of discrimination and marginalization of socio-economic, educational, cultural and geographical spheres of life in India. The dedication of CONSIDER is to achieve alternate models of development and sustained Human Rights among these disadvantaged communities in the State. In the context of disasters (both the natural and man made) the mission of CONSIDER is to respond to reduce the impact of disasters on the living conditions of the vulnerable and restore the life supporting systems of the victims of the disasters. The guiding force of CONSIDER is that the empowered people of the disadvantaged and vulnerable communities are in the mainstream of the society with a sustained â€œquality of lifeâ€. CONSIDER has been implementing various developmental projects in different thematic areas efficaciously with the funding from the donor agencies and with its own source of fund raising. It has the proven evidence of effective time bound and Result oriented project implementation and management. The staffs are experienced in various areas of programme implementation and have demonstrative ability to manage projects. It always maintains collaborative linkages with the government. It also has championed the cause of vulnerable coastal communities with the government officials in the area of Community Based Disaster preparedness measures. It is also providing leadership to the NGO Net Work (N-TIDES) to commonly address various developmental issues in Andhra Pradesh. CONSIDER has a highly varied and experienced management board and has developed an efficient system of management and bi-directional information flow. The management methods and systems of CONSIDER has been well accepted by international donors. The organization has up to date documentation and communication methods. CONSIDER has the partnership based relationship with the European Funding Agencies. MPDL Spain has been a partner of CONSIDER for Relief & Rehabilitation of Earthquake victims in Gujarat. ACT international in partnership with UELCI/IRDWSI has also been tapped for providing post-emergency relief to Flood victims and TSUANMI victims in A.P. ECHO funded EURO 450,000 to the project of Community Based Disaster Preparedness Programme in 260 communities during 2001-2004, has been a land mark in the history of CONSIDER. The model CBDP Project implemented by CONSIDER was also role model project at present for many NGOs in India It has the proven record of collaboration and coordination mechanism in reporting / financial transactions with transparency and accountability. CONSIDER also has received funding from DESWOS, Rotary Club, World Bank Provention Consortium, COL-PROTIEN of COMMON WEALTH, for Community Development, ICT and Risk Sharing programmes in AP. Apart from these, CONSIDER has well established advocacy linkages with the local, national and International organizations. It has collaborated with the said organizations, reaching thousands of vulnerable families, for addressing common issues of poverty, livelihoods, disaster preparedness, and disaster resilient houses sharing of information and achieved greater results and wellbeing of the marginalised sections of the society.
